The food was wonderful, the staff friendly and they graciously brought more bread with the side of feta, olives and wonderfully spiced butter without us asking. Water glasses were filled before reaching empty and they checked on us several times throughout the evening.

All three of us ordered lamb dishes that were cooked to perfection. One word of caution is if you don't like hot or spices in your food than this isn't the place for you.

As for dessert, I'd recommend the kannefe with unsweetened turkish coffee...though I thought the coffee was on the milder side. Otherwise, a satisfying evening.
author: Roya J.

description: The tiny dumplings were soo good!! They were so tiny!! The baked Eggplant was really good too. I definitely recommend these two dishes! The servers were really nice and helped explained things if I had any questions.
author: Charles Z.

description: The first 2 times I went to Tuba I loved it.  A good friend and I had gone last year for my birthday & hers.  We had the lamb shank which we both loved, the walnut red pepper spread which we also loved & several other dishes.  A nice extra was that they gave us a free desert and a gift certificate for $20 off for each of our birthdays.  The owner also stopped at our table  to help us select dishes.  We went back for my birthday on a Monday night & were both disappointed.  We learned that they only have lamb shank on the weekends so we got the seafood special.  It was good, but not as good as the lamb shank. We also got the filo appetizer with a potato filling, which was greasy.   And we got the walnut red pepper spread again but it just tasted hot with almost no walnuts.  We returned it & got a salad instead which was not bad. But the waiter didn't tell us that both the filo appetizer & the entree came with salad so we had a huge amount of salad left over.  They also didn't give us a free dessert or a gift certificate.  Very disappointing.
author: Joanne C.

description: Just went on a date with my husband, and we loved this place.  Tuba is a warm, friendly Turkish restaurant owned by a lovely Turkish husband and wife.  The food is gorgeous, especially if you like a little spice.  We started with the Icli Kofte (a signature app -yum!) and ended with the Turkish coffee (strong, smooth, quite a kick) and rice pudding.  Everything was delicious, fresh and flavorful.  A great local Mission gem - we'll be back soon!
author: Adrianne Y.

description:
I would eat there again. I didn't love it, but it was good.
I ordered the moussaka, which was bland, but maybe moussaka IS bland.

Maybe that's like saying macaroni and cheese is bland-I don't know.
I was trying to avoid eating an animal, because we can assume life sucks for an animal being processed for death. 
And then the anxiety when the kill is imminent; that's gotta be bad.
So I got the moussaka and watched my dc eat the chicken kebab. 
It looked really good. I kinda hoped it was dry.

Anyway, my motivation to write this is to save your life.
I went to find the bathroom. 
(These two things will come together.)

There was a little alcove, and a closed door with a bathroom sign on one side. 
On the other side was an open door. 
It was dark, I couldn't see what was in there. I noticed a white towel hanging against the wall, and I figured it was a utility room or another bathroom.

Before checking, I tried the handle of the bathroom door.
Locked, so I turned towards the open doorway to see if it WAS a bathroom.

By pausing for that one moment my eyes adjusted to the darkness and I saw that inside this doorway was a staircase...going down. 
Descending, I believe it's called, and it looked like a sudden descent, with paraplegia, possibly quadriplegia, or concussion and cracked rib maybe, at the bottom.

I was grateful I left with just a bland moussaka experience.
Don't walk through the door to your right.
author: Lame Lake Meese Z.

description:
Tuba is simply a gem! I love Mediterranean /Middle Eastern cuisine and Tuba definitely fulfill this craving.  

Couple weeks ago, I had to plan a special event for my parents, Plan A didn't happen so Plan B is to have the party catered last minute. I called Tuba because I love their food and I know that my guests will be happy. Jay came through big time. Met up with him in the restaurant and put together a scrumptious menu for 18 people. 

Appetizers we had, Dolma, Ezme, Haydari, Sigara and Mucver - excellent combo and everything tasted soooo yummy!

Entrée - 
Chicken Kebab - really moist flavor is good
Lamb Chops - grilled tender tasty chops
Adana Kebab - spiced sirloin beef and lamb - My fave!!

Dessert - Baklava - perfect to end the feast
author: Carrie F.

description:
I really want to give this place a higher rating but I just can't. The food just wasn't satisfying.

We came here on a double date night and had a good time. The reservation process is easy and flexible. The ambiance here is peaceful. I think it's perfect for date nights. It has a good intimate yet comfortable setting. 

The service here is good too. All staff members were more than willing to describe the menu and help us decide what to order.

For appetizers we tried the: 
1) Ezme - crushed walnuts, pepper paste, tomato paste, garlic, cumin 
2) Crispy Falafels - drizzled with tahini sauce
3) Mücver - pan fried zucchini patties with fresh dill  

For our entrees we had:
1) Adana Kebab spicy ground sirloin and lamb
2) Köfte Kebab ground beef and lamb, fresh herbs
3) Manti (some kind of meat dumpling)

For the appetizers, we all liked the falafels but none of us enjoyed the Ezme. The fact that it was a cold appetizer didn't help either. I didn't try the Mucver, but my boyfriend said he wasn't a fan. Our friends seemed to enjoy it though.

For our entrees. I had the Adana Kebab while my boyfriend had the Kofte Kebab. Both were alright but we have had better. The meat was well cooked and everything but I just didn't get nearly as much flavor out of it as I wanted to. My boyfriend felt the same with his Kofte Kebab. 

Our friends had the Kofte Kebab and the Manti.  I tried the Manti and it was good but I wasn't crazy about it. This dish was one of the restaurant's specialties. 

Overall I think the ambiance and service is good, but the food is lacking. I can tell they have put a lot of effort into their food and while the quality is great, the flavor is just not enough. The pricing was fair. It was about $15 for each kebab and about $6 for each appetizer.
author: Enza P.

description:
I came here with a friend for a drink before heading to the Academy of Science.

The interior of the place could make you stay there for hours. We sat by the window as the sun was setting and I could definitely imagine being on a date here.

The crowd is somewhat older and mellow which I like and the atmosphere is very sophisticated.

The service is friendly but not overbearing. We ordered a glass of wine, hummus and the crab cakes appetizers. All absolutely delicious. I haven't been back since but I've been dying to. It's one of those neighborhood favorites. I recommend anyone, no matter what type of palate, go in and try this place. You will not be disappointed.
author: Kathryn B.

description: The restaurant when full is incredibly noisy. That's the only reason I am rating at 4 stars instead of 5.  The food is simply awesome - better than I had in Turkey.   Good selection of Turkish wines which were fun to try.
author: Gretchen H.

description:
What can I say - I'm a fan of Tuba!
It's a great place for a date though I've also been with a group of six and it was perfect as well. The service is helpful and friendly and the food is tasty. Add those two points plus good ambiance and reasonable prices and you have a win. I recommend the moussaka for vegetarians (sort of a middle eastern lasagna) and the knaffi for dessert which is sweet crunchy cheesy bit 'o deliciousness.  I came of a Friday and didn't need a reservation which was also a big plus.
author: Summer N.

description: Every thing was so friggin' delicious! And they indicate what is gluten free, AND they are just the sweetest owner/staff. You need to go, eat some really great Turkish food and leave a wee bit of room for dessert and mint tea.
author: tara s.

description: Absolutely delicious! The appetizer plate is particularly stellar as are the lamb chops! Lovely people own and run this gem of a restaurant, they are very gracious and aim to please.
author: Miriam C.

description:
Ambiance
The host was welcoming and helpful.  The tables in the middle of the room are oddly organized and a bit cramped, but the food definitely makes up for it.

Appetizer
Tuba Hot Platter: I wish I could love this appetizer, but the items on this dish were not hot.  The Mucver were cold in the middle.  The items on this dish were definitely frozen then cooked again.   The falafel was absolutely DELISH though. It had a pleasantly surprising spiciness to it.

Main: 
Hunkar Begendi:  Very TASTY entree.  I loved the smokey flavor of the eggplant and saltiness of the lamb cubes on top.

Kofte Kebab:  Perfectly cooked and seasoned.  Not too salty or dry.  I loved the grilled peppers that were added to this dish.  

Dessert:  
Pyramid Noisette Chocolate: Not too sweet with a little bit of crunch on the bottom.  Really loved the hard texture of the chocolate covering and then the chocolate creamy texture in the middle.  A perfect end to our meal!
author: Sharon L.

description:
I love Tuba. I love it so much, it made my list of restaurants to go to when I was back in San Francisco for a week. 

I especially love the pureed eggplant with lamb dish. It has smokey mozzarella mixed into the eggplant, with roasted pepper and tomato on top. The lamb is really tender too. The vegetarian Moussaka is also delicious, covered in cheese with potatoes, eggplant, tomatoes, and spinach. The entrees are priced around $8-14 per plate. 

The restaurant is very classy, with a warm, comfortable atmosphere. The wine is pretty decent and reasonably priced at $6-10 per glass. It's almost never full on a weeknight, but come with a reservation on Friday or Saturday. 

Good service, comfortable space, great food, better prices, and an overall great experience.
author: Kealie G.

description:
YUM!!!  Early Valentine's dinner.

Shared the pistachio crusted prawn salad and the falafel to start.  The prawns were so fresh and delicious.  Lightly crusted and fried perfectly.  Went perfect with the salad that had a simple olive oil/lemon dressing.  Falafel was good as well - four decent sized ones that came with... the same salad (minus shrimp).  Oh well.

Entrees - hubby had the chicken shish kebab.  Perfectly seasoned chicken cubes on a skewer.  Amazingly tender.  Came with the same salad (argh) and rice.

I had the stuff salmon with fume sauce (light cream) and rice.  Of course, if you look at the menu, the question is... what is it stuffed with?  Sauteed spinach, but it's not stuffed. It's layered on top of the salmon.  You see that lemon wedge on the plate?  Make sure to give that sucker a good squeeze all over the dish.  It is incredibly delicious and it will be hard for me to order anything else the next time we come here.

The service was very friendly.  We had a nice conversation with our server.  Overall a very nice early Valentine's dinner and evening out.

I really recommend this place.
author: Denise M.

description:
Om nom nom.

Having recently moved back to SF after spending some time in Turkey, I've been enjoying the smorgasbord of food options in our fair city. However, sometimes the Turkish food craving kicks in, and you gotta satisfy it.

I've been exploring the Turkish places in the city, and while I haven't made it to all of them yet, Tuba is the best thus far.

Wandered over on a Thursday evening, and it was busy, but not packed. They were playing all the classic Turkish pop songs, so I was pretty pleased the moment I walked in.

I was even more pleased to see they not only have Efes, but they also have Efes Dark. SCORE. I hated Efes by the time I left Turkey, but now that I'm back in America and it's no longer the only beer option, seeing Efes on a menu makes me super happy. 

Being the "expert" on Turkish food, I was put in charge of ordering, so I opted for a sampling of mezes, as those are my favorite.

Cevizli Ezme: Delicious with bread. 
Kızartma: One of my favorite Turkish dishes, and it was pretty tasty here.
Sigara Böreği: I can't seem to find good ö outside of Turkey. It was okay, but not the best. If a restaurant starts serving spicy potato börek, I may change my mind.
Mücver: Pretty good, kind of hard to mess up.
Midye Tava: We ordered too much food, so by the time the mussels came, we were both full and feeling terrible. We managed to have a few, and they were good, but couldn't finish them. Mussels don't really keep well, either, for leftovers. Bummer.

We did get some Turkish coffee, which was the perfect way to cap off the meal. I don't know if they had çay, but I may get that next time too.

There's still a whole menu of things I need to try, but I think in the future, I'd go with a big group in order to sample all of the items.
author: Erin M.

description:
Cannot wait to come back again!

Everything was YUMS:

Eggplant puree with lamb - SUPERB - it's like home. Make sure you cube up the tomatoes for each bite.
Lambchops
Shrimp scampi was the best I've ever tasted
The manti dumplings were also a delight. 
Crab cakes
Falafels

Save room for dessert - bc I totally didn't. The first 4 dessert items are made in house.
author: Jessica W.

description:
Top notch experience! 

I went there with my husband and we were warmly greeted by owner and staff, and given a good table. 

Service was quick, attentive and the staff responsive.

Food was amazing and generously portioned! Appetizer was healthy and yummy. For my entree, I felt like I was back in Istanbul, enjoying a juicy,well seasoned, grilled kefta. Desert, the Knafe, was deliciously warm and sweet, and we were served Turkish coffee, with pride, by the owner himself.

The ambiance was lively, and thriving. Clientel is mostly non-Muslim, despite the food being halal. Yes they serve wine, but I was there to eat and wasnt particularly bothered by it.

The owner takes pride in his work and is humble in his service... 

I will always stop there any time Im in SF.
author: No E.

description:
Ohh sooooo good!! This place has been 3 blocks away for so long and it took a ScoutMob deal to make me realize. Absolutely delicious. Hummus, babaghanough and fried feta cover the familiar regional food, but kebabs, grilled meats and aromatic rice are so tasty and different. The service was perfect, the drinks were reasonable and there are always deals. Why does no one go here? It was empty when we went on a Friday night.

Totally delicious and moderately priced. Perfect for date night or a place to bring parents!
author: Emily G.

description:
I've been living rurally for 8 years, and have been without choices of restaurants. I lived in Turkey 15 years ago and claim the cuisine as my favorite. So obviously I was eager to remind my palate of the joys of Turkish food. 

Tuba was perfect!  The warm moody atmosphere calms the eyes and prepares the palate for exciting sensations. 

The staff is friendly, efficient and fun. The food is presented like art, and went beyond my expectations. Yes it is authentic Turkish, but it has a clean, crisp, fresh California quality that takes the traditional world cuisine to new scrumptious dimensions. 

Entrees are huge, so I suggest either doing meza's or having just the entree. We brought the rest back home and will have Tuba Turkish again tonight. 

I plan on visiting weekly!
author: Matthew T.

description:
Came here on Valentine's Day expecting to have a low-key dinner away from all of the Valentine craziness where restaurants force a jacked-up prix fixe menu on you -- and we were very pleasantly surprised!

The food was delicious, the service was efficient and friendly, and the ambience was cozy.  They had red heart balloons which made it festive, but not cheesy.  The owner was genuinely  appreciative that we were there, and this -- plus the great value and awesome flavors -- makes me want to come back again!
author: Carlo A.

description:
Add us to the list of 5-star fans. We stumbled upon this restaurant via OpenTable looking for a place in the Mission on a Saturday night. We wanted something new instead of the old favorites. Now a new favorite.

We're not much for meat and there is plenty on this menu to chose from. Two of us shared the cold appetizer platter and the mussaka. The mussaka was lovely and creamy. A terrific comfort food on a cool evening. The cold platter is a nice tasting of everything. Lots of fresh combinations, very fun and engaging. I like food that is more interesting than fussy and this place fits the bill. They brought extra bread with the appetizer platter, but you don't need it - they just fine to eat on their own, but the bread is good.

The one thing we found not particularly good was the rice that came with the Musakka, but honestly, no loss - didn't need it anyway.

Will definitely go back and you could bring friends who aren't particularly adventuresome about food and they could find something to love. Definitely a value in a city that can sometimes be short on them.
author: Jennifer e.

description:
good restaurent:)

a group of friends and I finally got around to try this place last night, and we had, overall, a nice experience here.

since there were 5 of us we ordered quite a lot of dishes. we tried their feta shrimp, tuba hot platter, shrimp scampi, sautee chicken, salmon, manti (beef dumpling) and lamb chops. they were all great. I might say this because i am not used to eating turkish food, but if anything, it was at least a great start.

lamb chop was fantastic, it was tender, perfectly seasoned thought one of my friend didn't agree. everyone else seemed very happy with their dishes as well.

their pyramid chocolate desert was quite memorable, what a presentation!
author: Sung C.

description: Delicious, but expensive. Not the most expensive place in SF by any means, but the entrees are pricey. Any of the meat dishes are phenomenal. The salads are good, but not my favorite.
author: B B.

description:
I have eaten every dish on the menu, and they are all a culinary vacation for my taste buds.  The flavors of roasted vegetables, lemon, cumin, garlic, and other fresh herbs are found in the roasted meats and vegetables, the delicious sauces and dips.
Nothing comes from a can in this place, and the food really is sensational.

The service is exceptionally friendly and attentive.  We NEVER go home disappointed, and are always eager to return.
author: Linda H.

description: I got the serma beyti kabab and it was really good. Also the serving size was huge.  My friend got a lamb shank and it was tender. The ambiance is really nice as well.  A typical meal will cost you between $30-$40 dollars here (without alcohol).  I'd recommend this place to others.
author: Mustafa R.

description:
I was skeptical to give this 5 stars (lets say 4.5 stars), but for a casual local joint, and considering I'm not really a fan of this type of cuisine, I was surprised.  This will def be a local spot to hit in the Mission!

Got a slew of apps, and we couldn't finish them all...the only that was off was the falafel but it was ok.  The dolma was def the best I've had...my sidekick despises dolma and didn't cringe at this one.   For a main I got the stuffed salmon, and this was terrific.  Great sauce, with a creamed-like spinach on the perfectly baked fish...yum!  And a side of rice...it was just rice, why couldn't I stop eating it?  The desert was their sig dish (can't remember the name), and it was a flaky sweet savory heart attack.  I wouldn't get again because it was too rich, but will def try others on the menu.  Capped off the night with a Turkish coffee which I've never had.  They spin it before serving, which I thought was gimmicky; however, we noticed the sludge at the bottom of the glass after finishing and realized it's probably needed to centrifuge out this potent bean.

The staff was friendly, the portions were big...I don't know how you'd judge this, but I'm on a mission to put on about 5 to 7 lbs people, and have been eating like a pig.  I couldn't finish the fish and went til I couldn't go anymore.   The only tacky thing was the lame wall art.

Great find in the hood and will be back again soon!
author: A A.

description: I can't believe we've lived two blocks away for a year and a half and haven't eaten here before now. Hands down one of the best (top 3) meals I've had in San Francisco.
author: Tess H.

description:
Excellent, great service, incredibly different and savory cuisine. Must try anytime they have a seat...

You'll especially appreciate the Owners, she works the kitchen, he the front. What talent and hospitality.

What you'll especially appreciate is the portions a reasonable prices.
author: William G.

description: Tuba is great in many aspects, the food, the service and the atmosphere. We were there during a weekday evening and it was nice quiet atmosphere. The owner was ver personal, remembering that I just had been there a month ago. We shared the cold mezzo variety, which I can only recommend, but all the other food I have tried there was very tasty. Definitely a restaurant I will go back to.
author: Ruth H.

description:
The kebab was very good.  The lamb chops were not as tender or flavorful as other reviewers gushed.  The stuffed falafal salad is humongous and makes a meal for one or an appetizer for 2-3.  They have a number of vegetarian options, including salads, eggplant dishes, and lentil soup. 

It's good for a date night type restaurant -- dark, red, and not too loud to carry on dinner conversation.  The seats have really high backs, which makes your table feel more private or secluded from others.  You're paying some amount for the ambiance and a huge wine list.
author: Elaine S.

description: The food was amazing and perfectly portioned! The only down side is that they only have wine and beer-- no cocktails-- but this will not deter me from going back!
author: Sarina H.

description: First time to go there tonight to celebrate a friend's birthday! The menu was very excellent! We were all very pleased with our choices...the presentation of the entrees was beautifully done! AND the desert was great! The waiter, very nice!  They even brought a beautiful desert for our friend and gave her a $20 coupon towards a future dinner! What a way to get her and us to come back again! Thank you!!!
author: Linda K.

description: This meal was great from start to finish! We were warmly greeted at the door and led to a nice table. Our server was attentive and helped us pair good wines with our dishes. The food was absolutely delicious! We ordered the lamb shank special and the meat was delicious, falling off the bone, and perfectly flavored. Combined with the bulgur, it was out of this world. For dessert, try Noah's Pudding. It's lightly sweet and the perfect way to wrap up such a meal. The little show with the delivery of the coffee is great, too. I had to take away a star because of the noise. It was difficult to hear my girlfriend speaking across the table. But we will definitely be back.
author: Jesse K.

description:
What a find.

We had gone on a weeknight via recommendation and couldn't have been more pleased. The virtually empty dining room (6:30-7p?) didn't seem like a good sign but with the fantastic menu and service, Tuba is a great place for a quiet weeknight dinner. We had the Crab Cakes, Mücver (bland-ish) and the Mixed Grill Kebabs (excellent!)

I'll definitely return to taste more of the menu .
author: Matt L.

description: This was the first time we've had Turkish. This place is amazing! The atmosphere is dark and cozy, very intimate. The service was personal and we were walked through it all, their suggestions should be trusted. The food was exceptional. I can't remember what food we had, but the signature desert was great. Overall, would recommend to anyone and will be returning.
author: Juan T.

description: I really love Tuba. The kebabs are awesome. They really know how to cook lamb. One of my favorite dishes is Hunkar Begendi. I like the cold Meze plate to share to start. The prices have gone up a bit, but it's still worth it. Great food, great service, and a comfortable place to eat. My family is from Cyprus, so this food fills my soul.
author: Wendy B.

description:
A friend and I arrived for an early dinner after a long day in San Francisco.  We were immediately given a choice of tables.  After a glance around at the surroundings, we settled on the window seat.  A plate of free bread was quickly served.  The sides of olives, cheese and seasoned butter paired deliciously with the bread.  When we finished the bread, our server promptly asked if we would like more.  The bread was delicious, but maybe a bit too filling.  We quickly declined the offer to save room for our main dishes.  

We'd ordered the Sigara Boregi and Kofte Kabobs to share between two people.  The Sigara Boregi was amazingly delicious.  They came piping hot, served with a salad and a yogurt cucumber dip.  The dip was the perfect for bringing a feeling of cleansing coolness to a crisp pan fried pastry.  The Kofte Kabobs was a plate that came with four succulent pieces of perfectly seasoned grilled beef and lamb, a grilled tomato and pepper, rice and marinated onions and julienned carrots and cucumbers.  The onions gave a spicy edge to the kabobs.  The rice softened the salt.  The food was amazing.  

The portions here was quite large.  We were quickly filled by the shared entree and appetizer (and didn't get to try dessert).  Our server was social, but knew how to give enough space.  We left very satisfied.
author: Eeway H.

description: The most  wonderful dining experience I've had in a while.. The dumplings were divine...can't remember what else we had but everything was very good.. The dessert wasn't the best though..some sort of fried pastry swimming in honey... It was OK... But everything else was excellent!! Would definitely come back. Try a sampler to get a taste of different dishes.
author: Marvin D.

description:
I came here on the recommendation of a friend. I'll have to thank her for tipping me off on this place. The food is great, portions large, and prices reasonable. 

My friend and I shared:

Tuba Cold platter: more than enough to share, great way to sample everything
Hünkar Beendi: delicious but I wanted more lamb!
Dessert: Hands down my favorite part of the night. Don't skip out on it. Ate the Künefe. It was wonderfully crisp and perfectly toasty. Ideal for cheese lovers:)

The wait staff was just OK.
author: Sofia R.

description:
My husband and I ate here on a Friday night - HIGHLY suggest reservations. 

The food was outstanding - We started with an appetizer - spinach, yogurt and garlic served with bread and feta, olives and herbed butter. Very nice dish. I had the Karides Tava, which is shrimp sautéed with wine, garlic asparagus, olive oil, and lemon juice, and was lovely. Very light, very flavorful. My husband had the Sarma Beyti Kebabı -- Adana kebab wrapped in lavaş bread and topped with tomato and garlic yogurt sauce -- also wonderful and flavorful. And we capped the meal with their signature dessert: Künefe layers of kadayıf (shredded fillo dough) filled with sweet cheese, served with homemade syrup and pistachio nuts. You can have it with ice cream, we opted to leave it plain. It was delicious as was the Turkish coffee - I asked for it not to be too strong and medium sweet and it was PERFECT.

It's a wee bit crowded, the tables somewhat closer than I like, but the atmosphere overall was very nice and relaxed. Our only quibble was the service was...strange. A waitress appeared almost immediately after we were seated to tell us the specials and then asked to take our order - being new to the restaurant, we needed more time to look over the menu, but she never came back. The owner/manager came over, asked if we wanted wine - we didn't - and then hovered a moment, so we figured he wanted to take our order, so we gave him our appetizer order and he said, "I will let them know" and left without taking our entree order. The appetizer arrived very quickly, but no one came back to take our entree order even though we still had the menus on our table. We were busy eating the appetizer and almost done with it by the time I realized our entree order hadn't been taken, so I told said something when our water was refilled and we finally made our order. The dishes arrived pretty quickly, so it wasn't like we were waiting forever for our food, but it was still strange. And the couple who was dining next to us had to ask repeatedly for a sharper knife to cut the lamb he had for an entre - the butter knife just wasn't doing the job even though the lamb was tender. 

So....great food...the service was strange for us, but not to the point that we wouldn't go back there again since we got our food in good time and it was all delicious (which is why we go to restaurants in the first place).
author: Venice G.

description: If you like lamb, you must go to Tuba!  Not only is the food amazing, but the service is excellent.  The owners are so kind and you can see their passion for the restaurant in every detail.  I tried a Turkish wine recommended by the owner that was awesome and paired perfectly with my dish.  We will be back again very soon!
author: Melissa S.

description: Wow! Totally awesome authentic Turkish food.  Everything was good, perfectly spiced, fresh and inspired. And an incredible value!!
author: Jack N.

description:
Having traveled in Turkey for over 20 years now, I feel safe to say that excellent Turkish food, one of my favorite cuisines, makes me glad to have traveled in such a wonderful place.  Good Turkish food makes me homesick for my home away from home.  And Tuba Restaurant, because of its owner/chef Ali Yaldiz, is a place to go for real home cooked Turkish food with a twist.  Ali is Kurdish, as are many of the best Turkish cooks in Turkey, and since he originally hails from the SE of the country, his specialties represent some of the oldest foods in all of Anatolia.

Ali has recently added a new addition to his comprehensive menu, PIDE, a delicious baked item that is a favorite with Turks, Kurds and visitors alike. 

PIDE begin as hand made dough, rolled thin, filled with an assortment of fine dry cured meats, special cheese varieties, vegetables and spices, crimped along its edges by hand, baked to perfection until just crisp around the edges but tender underneath, and served piping hot.

PIDE is the quintessential Turkish menu item that is served at small cafes, large hotels and in famous restaurants throughout the whole of Turkey, along the Aegean, Mediterranean and Black sea coasts as well in large cities and small villages all over the interior.

PIDE at Ali's Tuba Restaurant is as good as PIDE gets.  He uses the finest ingredients, as he does with all of his menu items, and prepares what may be the best PIDE that I have ever had in all of my years of experience with Turkish food here and in Turkey.

It is no wonder why PIDE is such a favorite of Turks young and old, because when it is done right, nothing is so sublime.  Ali and Tuba Restaurant really offer guests a chance to enjoy this secret specialty without the travel and without the jet lag.  PIDE at TUBA -- It doesn't get any better!  ENJOY!
author: Bruce I.

description:
Overall, the ambiance is above average. It is a very intimate setting and up your alley if you like dining by candlelight after dark. I loved the food, everything was incredibly delicious. 

You must make a reservation before you go, and they open @ 5pm.

I would visit again.
author: Ana S.

description:
The bottom line: I really wish the food had been better.

I *love* Turkish food. I grow rapturous about humus. I adore the mezes, the salads, the kabobs. I've had great Turkish food at many restaurants, in many cities (though never actually in Turkey).

Tuba was ... just fine. 

My husband had an interesting and unusual dish that was basically pureed eggplant with cubes of lamb on top. That was the only dish that stood out - the rest was fairly lacking in flavor or anything to distinguish them. 

I ordered the stuffed eggplant, which seemed to be stuffed with the same frozen peas, carrots, and corn medley that I buy at Trader Joe's. We started with the cold appetizer sampler which, again, with few exceptions, tasted like it could have been assembled from the TJ's dip counter. The humus was a big disappointment and just tasted like a can of chickpeas had been pureed with some garlic.

The good stuff: the restaurant has a great, cozy, romantic atmosphere. The waitstaff is friendly and attentive. That eggplant/lamb dish was yummy. I would go back to sample the kabobs (which many other yelpers rave about), but with so many other fantastic Turkish/Middle Eastern restaurants in SF (A La Turca, Troya, Fattoush) I'm in no hurry.
author: sarah b.

description: This was a great find on Guerrero. Authentic (exotic) turkish dishes, good (and not overpriced) wine, friendly service. I liked the decor (deep reds, candle light). I thought the chef was a bit skimpy on dish size but the taste and presentation more than compensated for this. Will be back.
author: Kai O.

description: Great Service and exceptional turkish food. Been here a few times and always happy. But recently I had the red pepper feta paste, the kofte and lentil soup. There were so outstanding I've decided they are my new standard for SF turkish food.
author: Monster B.

description: Had a friend who is half Turkish but living in Hawaii at moment. We suggested this place because we had run by a few times.  Food and service were awesome. I had a lamb dish, she had the pasta purses stuffed with meat. Awesome.
author: Mario P.

description:
According to Wikipedia "the tuba is the largest and lowest-pitched brass instrument". So, I won't lie, I had expectations of being greeted by a 15 piece brass band at the door. They must have been on a break when I got there.... but the lovely and authentic Turkish meal that followed more than made up for it.

The mixed grill was well seasoned, the aubergine dip was deliciously smokey and the icli kofte was nice and crisp on the outside but moist and rich on the inside (just served a little too cold, my only criticism on the night).

Will definitely be back again, maybe the tuba band will be there to greet me next time....
author: Matt T.

description: This was actually a really good meal!  We even bumped into a couple of friends who were regulars.  I ordered the shrimp kebab - two skewers of 4 tasty shrimp with lemon and pepper, with rice, yogurt, peppers and julienned carrots and zucchini.  It was really good.  For dessert, I had my favorite, baklava, which was gooey and sweet (as it should be).  I deducted a star only because my friend's dish was just drenched in a large pool of reddish oil and he spent a long time dredging the meat and sauce out from under it (it might have been a sautéed chicken).  Another friend ordered the moussaka which is vegetarian here (she was excited about that), and very creamy and cheesy (which she enjoyed).  Overall, it was pretty good, and the ambience is cozy and warm.
author: Vivian W.

description:
Food, fair. Had k-bobs and my wife had a spicy beef/lamb combo wrapped in pastry. Both were fine, nut really not much better than a frozen dinner 

Service was prompt and friendly
author: Rick A.

description:
Everything was delicious! We were a party of four, each with our own dish, so my introduction to Turkish food was fairly thorough. The appetizer platter was a good start to the meal- a nice taste of all the appetizers on the menu. The dolma were the best I've ever had.  

I had the matti (spiced beef dumplings) with yogurt sauce- the sauce was light slightly spicy and the dumplings were little meaty bites.
author: Andy S.

description: We came here twice in five days. Namely because we loved it the first time and had so much more to try. We really liked everything we got. The favorites were Cevizli, the soup, and the rice pudding. They do an amazing job with everything here when it comes to lamb and eggplant so you can't really go wrong with those either. Gracious service and reasonable prices for the big portions that you get. After writing this review I asked my wife if I should add anything and she said that she was a big fan of the ambience as well. After that she told me to stop typing and walking at the same time so I will end my review here.
author: Sai S.

description:
Turkish cuisine can be one of the Wonders of the World.  I happily traveled my way through this country several times, meals scattered between hair raising taxi rides, stimulating public bus transportation and nonstop encounters with friendly, inquisitive Turks eager to feed me. This comfortable restaurant is fine, but for its price it fails to introduce its guests to the best addictive and unique culinary experience that Turkey offers. We sampled the meza so we could sample all of the cold appetizers. The Hummous and grape leaves were no better than those available elsewhere.  However, the Cevizli and Kizartma (eggplant) were delicious. In a traditional Turkish neighborhood place, you would be invited into the kitchen to view and sample. The special of the evening was leg of lamb; two of us ordered it. Others ordered the Mussakka, sautéed shrimp and stuffed eggplant.  The lamb special came was well received (I didn't sample it). The sautéed shrimp , Mussakka and stuffed eggplant were also good, but doesnt the price demand something special?  Mussakka is a standard option in many Turkish and Greek restaurants, and this one was tasty, but again, was it distinguishable from the same dish served at other places?  The stuffed eggplant is also a classic dish which was well prepared.  My guests enjoyed the sautéed shrimp, but we wondered if it was a Turkish dish: not sure. The tab (including 2 glasses of wine and 2 turkish coffees) came to around $270 not including tip. I would recommend Tuba for those who want nicely prepared Turkish food in a comfortable setting, but after 3 trips here, I feel it falls short for its price. While not as comfortable, the offerings at Gyro King (especially the lunch specials) and Ala Turca are just as satisfying at a third the cost.  The truth is, I have yet to discover a Turkish restaurant that can match almost any Turkish truckstop wher you can sample an astonishing array of unique dishes not found here.  And where is the casual, family friendly Turkish neighborhood place that enthusiastically invites you into their kitchen, that asks you to smell and taste from their trays of colorful dishes?





x
author: Mark T.

description: Friendly staff, friendly servers and a great ambience. Pretty good food too. We had dietary restrictions on the table and one of the waitresses missed the fact that a particular dish was not dairy-free. But she was quick to fix it.
author: Jayesh P.

description: Amazing food! We had the Adana Kebab which was gluten free! Reminded me of the Turkish food I had in Germany. A very cozy and romantic atmosphere at the restaurant!
author: Ally N.

description: Very fresh and tasty Turkish food in a classy but casual setting. Impeccable service. Perfect for a casual date or dining alone. Highly recommend trying if you love Mediterranean food.
author: Kelly W.

description:
Service and ambience are nice.

Free flatbread at the beginning is nice... but in my opinion not flavorful enough, nor were the condiments next to it.
But the food is not good. We got the Hot Appetizers platter... everything was fried and pretty much taste the same.
My boyfriend got the lamb chops, which was the best dish out of the three we ordered. 
My chicken kebabs were slightly burnt and too dry. I didn't finish my plate.
We got the chocolate pyramid for dessert, and that was delicious!

Two stars go to service and ambience and dessert. I was not impressed with the appetizers or entrees and do not plan to go back.
author: Sonia S.

description: My fiancé and I were treated like family :) had no idea what to order. The owners son ordered for us. got a cold sampler and some amazing beef/lamb kebab dish for dinner!!! Turkish wine was also delicious. Will definitely return for another date night
author: Allyana W.

description:
I have had virtually everything on the menu at this point, so I suck for not having written a review until now. That said, I have a lot of data to draw on for you! 

Although this place is technically Turkish, the food is very similar to Greek and other Middle Eastern food.....in case you were wondering. However, here it is hands-down much better than most places I've been....and I have been a food-obsessed/gardener/cook/eat-out-a-lot person for the 20 years of my adult life. There is just something about the quality of the food and the way it is lovingly prepared at this place.

This is my first five star review for a reason - it's consistently very high quality, the portions are huge, the service is really good and often the chef will come out and check to see how you are doing. The ambiance is pretty nice too, although the only knock I can possibly think to give it is that sometimes it gets a little too packed with people and then it gets too hot because the kitchen is going full steam...but they will open the front door if no one objects.

OK, let's start with the service: very attractive and sweet female servers (I believe they are all Turkish too), super helpful at picking out wine from their extensive list, I have also seen then handle a couple of difficult situations with grace and leaving the customer feeling good.

The food: did I mention HUGE portions? You can easily get full on the appetizers and amazing bread, but be careful not to because you really want to leave room for the rest of it. The lamb is always cooked to perfection, the shrimp is succulent and good in every dish it is in - but especially the Pistachio Crusted Prawn Salad, their falafel is not too dry and full of flavor, I loved their zucchini appetizer and the lentil soup....I even tried their eggplant dish with my friend who is veggie and liked that (and I don't usually care for eggplant unless the flavor is completely masked.)

When should you try this place? Any time you have people in your party who are vegetarian, vegan, picky or indecisive - I've been here with all of these types and everyone has left happy and full. Also, just come here for a date or when you want one meal to last you for three in leftovers. I've been here going on 10 times in the past year. Enough said.
author: Rachel K.

description:
I was thoroughly impressed with this place. We had a group of four so we did family style so we could sample a lot of the dishes: 

Appetizers: Ezme and Sigara Borei 

The Sigara was delicious. They were like these scrumptious, feta-filled egg rolls. The Ezme, which was a spread you put on pita, was pretty good but there's probably better options.

Entrees: Lamb Chops and Mixed Grill

All very moist and tasty. The lamb chops were certainly the star.

Dessert: Künefe

I've never tasted a better dessert in my life. I'm not kidding. I was thinking about this dessert into the next day (mostly about how I can reverse engineer this dish and make it at home). It was sooo good: crispy sugar-glazed filo dough, gooey, savory cheese, and crushed walnuts and pistachios. You couldn't invent a drug to target more human pleasure receptors.
author: Theodore B.

description: We started the meal with the heydari and it was so fresh and light. The mixture of dill and garlic was perfect. The falfafel salad was huge and made it easier to digest the amount of meat we were going to consume. The mixed grill is the way to go. You get a little of all their kebabs. I am pretty sure we really had the whole farm at our table but it was delicious. All the meat were seasoned well and tender. The lamb chops were the favorite. I guess Old McDonald lost his farm to us last night.
author: Eve C.

description:
I quite like this place. The service is good, the food is really good, and I think they pay attention to details well. Being able to make reservations make the restaurant experience so much better, and I am glad this place makes that process so convenient. The tables are a little close together for my preference is all, I am pretty sure every table spends the evening just listening to what other people are saying in between talking to their own table mate(s). Such is the restaurant experience in SF I guess.

Get the cold meze plate, so you get a try a bunch of different things. If you get a turkish coffee or a mint tea, look forward to the waiter spinning the tray in a 360 motion, and then joke about how they might have spilled scalding hot liquid in your eyes. Haha, those guys are a cut-up!
author: Dustin Y.

description:
My friend and I went to this place for the very first time just this past Sunday.  We had no reservations and her little two-year old with us.  When we arrived the place was packed and there was about a 45 minute wait.  As badly as we wanted to wait, we simply did not have the time.  As we started to head back to the car, the owner ran out and told us that if we sit tight for just 10 minutes he would make the room to accommodate us and that's just what he did.  From the first impression all the way to last, we were amazed.  

The food, presentation and atmosphere were outstanding but what really stood out is how the owners and staff made us feel like family.  It's hard to find an experience like this and when you do, it's very memorable.  Of course we learned our lesson for next time...make the reservation regardless the day or time.
author: Christopher G.

description:
I'm a huge fan of Persian food. Though the cuisines are similar, I had never had Turkish, so my cousin suggested that we meet here. It's located on busy Guerrero St., and visiblly close to the corner of 22nd St. 

I found a parking spot on the next block. What I love about SF - are little pockets of businesses/restaurants at intersections such as this one - a little urban oasis nestled in between The Mission and Noe Valley.

I walked into a really cozy, yet modern space, with no more than a dozen to a dozen and a half tables, maybe. The walls were colored a deep, warm red; the tables and chairs were made of dark wood; the really chic lighting and pops of colorful art really made the aesthetics inviting and comfortable. 

The server came by to take our drink order, and was taken aback, and perhaps offended that I wanted a Turkish coffee before dinner. She said that it wasn't too great for digestion...yet she doesn't realize that I've had it before, and drink coffee as easily as I drink water! I still asked for it.

There was flat bread on the table, and it wasn't pre-packaged, or dry, compared to anywhere else that I've had it. It had a really great texture, yet was soft, and moist, like homemade American bread.

My companions had ordered the hummus (which came with more flat bread), and it was super creamy, smooth, and the BEST that I have ever tasted. You could tell from the texture of it that it was "super homemade." ...and I now realize that most places probably have it pre-packaged.  It also wasn't oily and didn't have the puddle on the top like you find at other restaurants

For my entree, I ordered the Adana Shish -
Spicy ground sirloin and lamb at $15. 

I tried to order it extra spicy, but understandably, they couldn't do it because the meat was pre-mixed/pre-prepped with the spice.
 
Shockingly, my entree arrived before I had a chance to finish my Turkish coffee! I'd say it was less than 15 minutes to wait for my food - which was cooked to order, and nice and hot.

The shish was really super moist. It came with a grilled tomato, a grilled chile pepper, a large (but not overkill) serving of rice, onions, dill yogurt sauce, and of course, the shish kebab at maybe a foot long. 

Note that the beef/lamb meat combo is usually a really good flavor combination because you don't get that overpowering taste from the ground lamb, yet, you also get the natural beef fat from the ground sirloin to juice-it-up. 

Since I asked for extra spice, they served me up with a helping of hot sauce! All-in-all, it was enough food to keep you full in the stomach, yet not so much that it sends you over the edge with a to-go box to boot!

For dessert, I ordered Baklava $6), which I NEVER pass up. The layers of filo were thin and flaky, which was good, and had some honey in it. This was definitely one of the best I have ever tasted, and not dry like I've had at most places.

To summarize, I would have given this place five stars if it weren't for the mediocre service. Not to the fault of anything or anyone, with the exception of circumstance, there was a slight language barrier with the server. Note that this is NOT a criticism. It's merely a trivial thing yet at the same time, a large enough interaction for me to remember it.
author: Jimmy L.

description:
Tuba is very easy to review: great venue; great people and service; great food; and a really, really great price.   The owner and staff are warm, friendly, competent people.  They made it clear that they wanted me to enjoy my meal and I certainly did.  It's really a shame that local restaurant reviewers don't review places like Tuba, as places like this are what make a city great for people who appreciate food.  

I started with the very nice, thick and hearty, lentil soup.  What was very good became great when I squeezed some juice from the lemon on the plate into the soup.   Wonderful start to a meal.  

I almost forgot to mention the great bread that comes to your table gratis.  The spread, cheese, and olives that accompany the bread are a treat.  

For a main course I had the mixed grill.  I am an expatriate New Yorker and almost a walking food compactor.  Yet even for me there was enough great food on this plate to have shared.  The chicken kabob was moist and perfect. The lamb kabob and lamb chop were very good.  Likewise the kofte and adana.  Of note, the rice and dip that accompanied the meats were great and the onions and carrots were perfect and perfectly wonderful.  

The Turkish wine suggested by my pretty young server paired very well with my meal.

I left feeling good about the world.  And all because of Tuba.
author: David D.

description:
hands down one of the most underrated places in sf but i'm secretly glad because we all know once it's gets popular, we'll have to code a bot in order to get reservations

been here before but came more recently with my boyfriend who is from bulgaria which is near turkey!

literally five stars for everything. i absolutely loved this place. my boyfriend and i came in starving and we were soooo full by the end of it but everything was extremely delicious!

İçli Köfte - both apps were absolutely delish. wouldn't know which one to go with if i could only pick one..
Cevizli Ezme - loved the walnut taste
Somon - spinach was so creamy and the salmon was cooked to perfection!
Kuzu Pirzola - you can barely tell it was eggplant. it was so creamy. the meat was also very generous and the taste mixed very well with the eggplant
author: Janet Y.

description:
Cute little Turkish restaurant with good service and pleasant decor.  The food is tasty and quite hearty.  I had the adana kebab, half of which ended up boxed to go.  The Turkish coffee I had after my meal was pretty good too.  Standard.    

Why only three stars?  

It felt pretty damn cramped in there.  The aisles are small and just getting to and from my table was not graceful.  I had to dodge a waitress on the way in, and be mindful of the way my purse swung on my way out.  If the edge of my chair wasn't getting knocked whenever someone walked by our table, my companion's elbow was.  Just moving a chair across the room was a major to-do for one of the waitresses and everyone had to make room as she passed.  There were simply too many interruptions throughout the evening due to the tight spacing.  

Then there was the noise level.  It got a little over the top several times while we were there.  Perhaps the fact that we were seated so close to other tables may have had a little to do with it.  Whatever it was, I lost my train of thought several times while speaking and we had to repeat ourselves more than a few times to hear each other across our own small table.  

Parking in that 'hood is not easy to come by either.
author: Carol Y.

description:
We decided to try Tuba since it was on our list of to trys and the pics of their food looked sooo good.Plus we had Scoutmob which helped the cause even more. Everything was sooo good. 

Me n the BF ordered the mixed grill, Turkish tea and coffee. Everything was fresh and came out out in a timely fashion. The wait staff was attentive and cordial as well. We shared the plate and it was more than enough.

 The mixed grill is awesome considering it has a little of every thing they have on the menu in it and the rice is to die for or maybe i just thought so since we been on a health kick and I hadn't had rice for like a month so I ate it like it was a serving of candy. The fresh bread they serve while you wait for your food is piping hot with a delectable trio of sauces and olives.....we wanted more but refrained cuz we knew we'd be full if we didn't even give the meal a chance.

I am glad we came here on an off day cuz the yelp pics look crowded and busy and we got lucky and had basically only like 3 other tables filled when we arrived. We will be back!
author: Ro M.

description: I can't pronounce half of the dishes we devoured here, but I'm sure a few unicorns died for our gastronomic sins. Shout out to the older gentleman, who I assume was the owner, for sharing with us his newly concocted, delicious bread spread.
author: Yumanti A.

description: first experience with Turkish food and it was fantastic.  2-3 blocks from the 24th/mission bart station.  felt a bit silly with our 6:15 reservation as we were the first ones there but by 7 pm there was a line out the door.  food was creative, really delish and we were stuffed when we left.  had the Cevizli Ezme (a touch spicy and so good with their homemade bread) Karidesli Salata (really good size bowl of salad perfectly dressed with 4 huge shrimp) Adana Kebab (very tasty with variety of enhancements such as a yogurt sauce, pickles, peppers and finally Hünkar Beğendi (absolutely intoxicating eggplant, a few chunks of peppers and a nice sauce.  the food was a bit slow to come out at first but they got busy so fast!  excellent friendly staff.  can't wait to go back!
author: Pm H.

description: Freakin amazing the ravioli burrito is to die for. There goes my diet. I think the word is love I  use your love.
author: John H.

description:
I forgot the name of the dish i had, and it wasn't on their online menu... but it was dumplings with lamb... it was delicious... I just wish it was hotter (temperature wise... why don't restaurants in SF like serving hot food? everything is kind of luke-warm)...  my friend had the chicken kebab and she says she always gets it when she goes there... so i know she likes it...

atmosphere was cool it's definitely worth going back to
author: Aarash Z.

description: Walnut and hot pepper mash measured into ones head with unleavened bread; insanely good prawn dish with a sauce which warranted mopping to the very last morsel.
author: Donald C.

description:
I decided to host a 14-person dinner at Tuba on a Saturday night, which turned out to be a great success. The manager was incredibly accommodating as he worked around my tight budget. The night of the dinner, two extra people showed up and he was able to fit them in without a problem.

The food was flavorful and creative. I really enjoyed the stuffed eggplant and the baklava. Many of my dinner guests commented afterwards on how much they enjoyed their dishes. I definitely recommend this place!
author: Polina S.

description:
Tuba offers the whole package.  I made the reservation for the wrong day and when I called the day of to change it, they were very accommodating and fit us in for that day even though it was a Friday and they were already completely booked.  

The waiter was also great helping us with the menu and offering the best dishes of the house.  The owner came out to introduced himself and gave us a little history of the place including how his wife is the chef!

Our fav dished were the cold appetizer dish- perfect sampler plater,  lambs and ravioli were also excellent.  

We are definitely planning to go back!
author: Francisco R.

description: The best Turkish restaurant in America. Authentic food. Attentive staff. Great Cofeee.
author: Chris H.

description:
Waitress: "Shep tra lek vun te um"
Me: " Um, yes...I'd love a glass of red wine.
Waitress: "Bar de good'n, wan mument plece"
Me: "Thanks"
Waitress returns in 10 minutes with a glass of Malbec.
I swear that neither of us understood each other...but we spoke the universal language of food.  Turkish Food.  
Wasn't bad...wasn't great.
We had cold and hot offerings, none of which blew me away.
Cozy spot...reasonably priced...I can't entirely pan this one.
I just can't trumpet about Tuba either
author: Mark C.

description: awesome. get the whole fish (sea bream), manti (ravioli like things in yogurt sauce),  lamb chops, hunkar begendi (meat cubes on a bed of pureed roasted and creamed eggplant dish).. trust me, this place it Turkish citizen approved (its Turkish cuisine) and it is absolutely yummy! Cute place too.
author: C A.

description: Great food, especially the dill/cucumber yogurt and the kofte. My only complaint is that I think it's a tiny bit overpriced, as the portions aren't as large as typical mediterranean dishes.
author: Samantha H.

description:
I was greeted with warm and friendly service on a Saturday at 6:30pm. Around 7-7:30pm, the restaurant filled up. The small and intimate size and deep red walls makes the ambiance cozy. As I waited for my cousin, the owner talked to me and was very nice. I started with a glass of wine, while I perused the menu. I wanted to try a Turkish white wine, and so the server described the 3 that they have, so I chose the Kavaklıdere Cankaya, like pinot grigio, which I liked. They started us with their complimentary bread with olives and spreads..mm..
We shared the:
1. Cevizli Ezme Walnuts, Turkish red pepper paste, tomato paste, fresh garlic, olive oil,
and cumin  Signature meze (my favorite)
2. Sigara Böreği Fillo dough stuffed with potatoes, feta cheese, parsley and a touch 
of black pepper
3. Karides Tava Shrimp sautéed with wine, garlic, asparagus, olive oil, lemon juice 
with rice and veggies
All were good though we talked so much and were in a rush to a comedy show, so they were
nice to give us the bill and pack the food quickly.  I would come back to try other items.
author: Catherine B.

description: Excellent service and delicious and interesting food.  We loved everything we ordered, all things recommended by our waiter who was so happy and eager to make suggestions.  We started with cevizli ezme and hummus.  The cevizli ezme and homemade bread was out of this world.  We also shared a light and fresh cucumber salad.  My husband had a lamb special and I had the Sarma Beyti Kebab.  We each thought we ordered the better entree.  Yum!  And lots to take home too.  The portions are huge.  We will definitely be back, perhaps even with our kids.
author: Margaret F.

description:
- food: hit or miss
- atmosphere: cozy and loud
- staff: perfunctory
- price: fine

additional info:
- shrimp dish was overcooked
author: J. B.

description: I wanted to try this restaurant because I LOVE middle eastern food. My boyfriend is Egyptian, so we are always searching for great authentic middle eastern restaurants in the city. Like Brian below - we had some issues with the guy in the front. We came here earlier than our reservation to see if there was an open spot. Instead of saying "unfortunately we don't have anything until XX" he acted like a stuck up prick. WHAT? So, we left and will never come back. Management needs to fire the stuck up short guy in the front, he is driving all your customers away. If you want good middle eastern food, try Mazzat, El Mansour, or Saha (their food is good AND they are nice to their customers).
author: Melanie S.

description:
I loved this food!    We chose to start with the combination appetizer selection, which was enough food for two just by itself. We really liked each of the flavors...my husband ordered a meat entree which was good too. 

(Entree's are smaller than American portions, as the Turks eat a variety of small plates, almost like dim sum, so an entree is simply that, without a lot of extras on the plate)

I used to live in Turkey, and I can unequivocally say, the food is as good as or better than I have had in Turkey.

Attentive staff too.
author: Barbara W.

description:
Got to try this place with a Groupon 2 yrs ago.  And have been back several times.
Can't say enough.  Food is wonderful, price is right and service is stellar.  Even the owner will come around to ask how everything was.
It has become one of my places to take friends and family.  You will not be disappointed should you give it a try.
author: Sandra M.

description: Thought everything we had - from the hummus to the kebab to the stuffed salmon - was tasty, thoughtfully prepared - cute slow-paced place. So great!
author: Andrew K.

description: We'd heard good things about this but it was excellent.  I have only had Turkish food once before so I can't say whether it's "authentic", but everything was flavorful and fresh, and the service was prompt and friendly.  We're definitely going back!
author: A.J. F.

description: I don't know if it's "authentic" or not since I have not yet been to Turkey. But I love this place. Delicious food, great ambiance, friendly staff (most of the time). My favorites are the Ezme appetizer and Falafel stuffed with Goat cheese salad. I also liked their Turkish wine (don't recall the name, but it was a white). It's not easy to get a reservation though unless you are eating late (after 9pm).
author: What's in a nam e.

description: Fabulous food, attentive service. Nice ambiance. Easy street parking. One of my favorite places. I would go outta my way to eat here, anytime. Do make a reservation though.
author: Linda P.

description:
Went to check out this place for date. I was looking for a spot with great but reasonably priced food, with a little exotic flair and a sheik atmosphere, and that's exactly what I got. 

The interior was really cool looking; romantically lit with red tones and pillows about, but it was too hot to sit inside. The food was excellent and came quickly. The staff was helpful and our water glasses never emptied. Additionally they have one of the best beers I've had, Efes, which I cannot find anywhere.
author: Anthony P.

description: Tuba restaurant is decent in terms of wine and food selection. The Turkish food they offer is one of the best in the Bay Area. The only downside of Tuba is the dishes are relatively expensive and I wish the prices were ~20% lower. Definitely I will keep taking all my Turkish friends over there.
author: Volkan E.

description:
Had last minute plans to head up to SF on a Friday night and decided to dine at Tuba Restaurant based on 1) availability on OpenTable, and 2) 1000pt reservation.

AMBIANCE: Extremely dim inside the restaurant-- I guess they're going for a sexy/mysterious vibe, what with the lack of lighting and all the cushions.  The restaurant space is small, and was crowded when we arrived.  There is no dedicated waiting area, so the majority of diners waiting for a table have to huddle awkwardly by the door, or lurk next to someone's table. 

SERVICE: Friendly, apologetic... but... not the greatest.  For one thing, we arrived a few min early (5) for our 8:30PM reservation, only to be told by the owner (? An older gentleman) that he was so sorry, but we would have to wait a few minutes, on account of our early arrival.  Ok, NBD, we stand outside the doorway like awkward creepers and check out their menu.  We ended up waiting for over 15min before I requested to be seated outdoors.  They quickly set up the table, and we ordered pretty much immediately upon sitting down.  It took them another 15min to bring us water, which they never refilled.

FOOD: The food arrived lukewarm to cold at our table... which was quite unappetizing.
- Falafel ($7): Very loosely packed falafels (4) with a small mound of hummus.  This app came out nice and hot, and was fairly satisfying.  I prefer a denser falafel but the flavor of these were good.
- Mercimek Corbasi (bowl $7): Red lentil soup in a bowl was a decent sized portion, but did not come out quite as hot as I would've liked.  It had a pretty sour edge (the addition of the accompanying lemon wedge was a bit overkill)... the versions of lentil soup I had while in Turkey were never this sour, and were way more savory.  This was mediocre at best.
- Sebzeli Guvec ($18): A lamb cube casserole with assorted veggies (zucchini, bell peppers, onion).  The lamb was really gamey, but the worst offense was that this dish was COLD.  J said his half was fine, but practically every bit I ate was ice cold in the center.  So unappetizing!  The side salad was nicely (lightly) dressed, and the rice was fine.

OVERALL: Having to wait more than 10+min for a table when we had a reservation already put Tuba Restaurant on the naughty list.... The kicker was the COLD FOOD, which really turned me off from Tuba Restaurant and earned it a 2star rating.  Price seemed to be reasonable for SF (~$40 including tax+ tip for 2 apps & 1 entree), but I will not be returning.
author: Susanna W.

description: Delicious! Nice atmosphere and good service. They even brought me a delicious little dessert for my birthday and sang. Server recommendations were spot on. Would definitely eat here again.
author: Nawal W.

description: Our food was excellent. The two of us shared the Cevizli Ezme (A rich dipping spread for bread), İçli Köfte (Like a gourmet hot pocket), Mercimek Çorbası (Lentil Soup), and Hünkar Beğendi (pureed eggplant with lamb). They were a nice cross section of what the menu offered, and we were so full that we couldn't touch the dessert menu. The service was attentive and helpful. The atmosphere is nice. It was just an all around good experience. I will be back to try the stuffed eggplant dish I saw others having which looked amazing.
author: Sean Q.

description:
Came here for a facebook holiday team dinner and these fbooker engineer folks sure know their stuff... Such a cool spot, order the masaka and lamb chops and def order the cheese pistachio pastry thingy- Delicious middle eastern desert done French and buttery.

Reasonable prices, very authentic, and they even have an evil eye on the doors- love it!
author: Mariam A.

description:
Spent a few weeks in İstanbul earlier this summer, which has left me with a nonstop craving for Turkish food/humor. So when some friends asked me to pick a spot for a mini-reunion, I had to choose Tuba. 

The food was excellent, if slightly overpriced, and my friends who had never tried Turkish food before were both excited we weren't the loudest ones in the restaurant and happy to have been induced into pleasant Efes-boosted food comas. 

The best part of our night was our sarcastic-but-likable server, who poked fun at our butchering of the Turkish words on the menu between jokes about how many beers we'd ordered.
author: Nyki S.

description: The food was authentic and delicious. The wait staff was very friendly. The un-authentic aspect of the restaurant was the typical "turn the tables" mentality. This doesn't happen in Turkey and Europe - the table is your's for the night. I was disappointed when the wait staff took everyone's plates while I was still eating and even gave them the dessert menus while I was finishing my meal.  We were served our desserts and the bill came immediately, before asking if we wanted a coffee or espresso, which, in my opinion, isn't a dinner out without an espresso.  Highly recommended if you're not as fussy as me about good waiter manners and service. Authentic food with American service.  Booooooo.
author: Steve D.

description: Fun and authentic Turkish dinner! Staff was all welcoming and loved to hear we had visited Turkey. Food was fresh and flavorful and there were good vegetarian options! Fun spot and good food!
author: Julia W.

description:
I had a groupon which was about to expire so I last minute threw together an event. 

I made a reservation for 4 but due to classic SF flakerism, 2 people cancelled/no showed. I miss the east coast where people show up when they say they will. 

The place was packed so I was feeling anxious to get my food. We order the feta prawns to share as an app and for dinner, we get some sort of homemade meat stuffed pasta in cream sauce and plenty of bread (amazing btw). 

1) The decor was not that impressive. We could have been in any fancy restaurant. It didn't scream Turkish culture. 
2) Service was nice and friendly and always checked on us for water. They didn't bat an eye when I said 1/2 the party flaked. 
3) Portions were a little skimp but w/ the bread, the pasta and app filled me up. I wouldn't come here starving though. 
4) Prices are decent. 
5) Good for a first date, as music wasn't too loud and the place is cute. 

I need to come back as this review is written months after the visit. There are several things I want to try on the menu as well. Maybe there will be a Townhog for this soon.
author: Angelo F.

description: I was so excited to find Tuba. A place where my carnivore boyfriend and my Vegan/ GF self could both get a good meal without compromising the overall satisfaction of one another. The staff was very friendly and accommodating to our questions about the menu. The owner even brought my boyfriend a sample of a dish he couldn't decide on (he ordered more). Great ambiance, amazing food and perfect overall experience. I'll be back to Tuba again.
author: Brianna B.

description: A restaurant that surely entices and delivers with exceptional flavors, Tuba, which literally means, and I quote the son's owner,  "an upside down tree hanging from the heavens - to grant people an easy way to pluck its fruits" traverses Turkish and Mediterranean faire beautifully. There's plenty of vegetarian option, and a Sebzeli which is a wonderful plate of eggplant and veggies in their savory sauce. They also have kebab for the meat eaters. But a great selection of cold and hot mezes for both vegetarians and non-vegetarians to share. The place is spacious, so tables are certainly not on top of each other. Lastly, they serve super ice cold beer - great for a warm night.
author: Claude C.

description: I came in here Sat before last with a friend, and they were full, but cleared a space at the bar for us to sit.  We just had a few appetizers which were tasty, but not spectacular, but I think we ordered the wrong things, because other things went by that looked even better.  They were very nice however, and we sat there for ages drinking wine and talking, and everyone who worked in the restaurant stopped by and chatted with us.  They were so nice and friendly I decided to make reservations there for the next weekend for another friend's bday.  This time in a larger group we got real food.  The mixed cold appetizer plate was tasty, and I had split the lamb shank entree which was HUGE.  Even the two of us could not finish it.  Again, everyone stopped by the table to chat, and when they found out it was my friend's birthday they of course presented us with dessert, sang, etc.  And you know what it was really sweet, not at all like when I was a teenager and worked at Swensen's ice cream shop and I had to sing happy birthday to all the kids who came in for their birthday parties.  In my old timey Swensen's uniform, just dying of embarassment.    So Tuba, nice, friendly, tasty food.  Split the entree.  Good for birthdays.
author: Nicole B.

description: A great place with delicious food. And the people working here are courteous and very  nice.
author: Anujnath P.

description:
Another pleasant surprise of a restaurant! The bread and dip they provide at the beginning of the meal is ultra-addicting. I think I filled up on this too quickly...

Chicken kebab tender and juicy , stuffed salmon buttery and delicious. Cute interior as well - great service!
author: Carol L.

description: The lentil soup is a must. Staff was very friendly and efficient. Absolutely nothing to complain about.
author: William B.

description: We enjoyed an al fresco experience on the sidewalk on a gorgeous warm night. The host was charming and offered us the choice of the two top outside or inside. The waitress was efficient and friendly.  The appetizer was enough for the both of us plus some to take home with the homemade bread. The lamb was tasty and the eggplant was really good.  For dessert we had the rice pudding, rich and creamy.
author: Lhm M.

description: Can't believe I waited this long to try Tuba! I had heard good things, but there is so much mediocre Mediterranean food in San Francisco, I figured it would be more of the same hum drum falafel and hummous. So wrong! We ordered a range of dishes from cold and hot mezes to salads and entrees. Everything was perfectly prepared and full of flavor. I've never been to Turkey but this seemed authentic in that the dishes did not seem to be "Americanized" but rather had interesting ingredients and flavors i haven't had at other Mediterranean places in the bay area. I encourage people to order things they don't recognize--you will be pleasantly surprised. We also had some delicious Turkish wines. Service was impeccable. We were with friends that we hadn't seen in a long time, and they allowed us to order slowly and were attentive without disrupting the flow of conversation. It also has a great neighborhood feel -- clean and warm, with a relaxed vibe. Will definitely be back.
author: Rob K.

description: Wow, what a most delicious spot to dine accompanied by excellent service with a home style feel and taste.  I have been looking for a good Mediterranean Restaurant in the area but have been disappointed all too many times by the dried out meats served.  Tuba makes you feel like you are dining around the Mediterranean and exceeded my expectations.  Their lamb chops were juicy and exquisite!  The vegetables on the sampler plater were fresh and tasty.  The owners were a lovely couple who approached the tables and watched with a caring eye that their patrons were satisfied.  When I looked around the room everyone was smiling. I can't wait to go again!
author: Pickle S.

description:
Debating that fourth star:

Reasons why: Friendly. Generous portions. Buzzing atmosphere. Delicious menu. Absolutely rocking cold appetizer platter.

Reasons why not: The sauteed chicken in tomato sauce would more accurately be described as sauteed chicken in a way, way too oily tomato sauce. I prefer my dinner without an oil sheen that looks like BP was in the kitchen.
author: Jason B.

description:
Tuba makes me think of the huge musical instrument that a band member plays.  It's loud, somewhat obnoxious, and super intimidating.  However, Tuba, the restaurant, was nothing like the musical instrument.  I was quiet, very inviting and sensitive to me needs.  It seems like it would be a great date place.  Warm inviting colors and a very prominent Mediterranean theme made me completely comfortable.  

I went to dinner with my friend Sameer Y. and began the night a glass of Turkish wine.  We followed that up with the Tuba Cold Platter, which i thought was delicious.  I loved the variety.  I would say there were about 7 different things on this platter.  Everything was tasty.  For our main course I had the Musakka and Sameer had the Stuffed Eggplant.  Both were delicious and super filling.  I have to say that their portions are quite generous.  Overall, this meal was satisfying and the service was great.  

The only thing i have to warn  you about is that after eating here, i wouldn't suggest going out unless people around you don't mind Mediterranean food burps.  My burps were potent that night. eek! so embarrassing.
author: Aaron G.

description:
Fresh, delicious Turkish food served in a bustling, small, bistro-like format.  The cold mezze platter was delicious, as was my glass of Jade cabernet that the waitress recommended.

Service was quick. The stuffed falafel salad was rated highly by other Yelpers- mine was fine- but the cold mezze platter was much more memorable.

All in all, a great place for dinner with friends.
author: Aimee Y.

description:
Tuba is an unassuming neighborhood restaurant and that's what makes it so charming.

Service is always excellent, professional yet friendly and always warm.

Good selection of wines. Try a turkish wine! A rarety! The whites are especially good if you like a dry, slightly mineral taste ( which I do).

The food feels more like comfort food: hearty soups, thick sauces, grilled meats, all very tasty. Salads are excellent and huge.
author: Eli E.

description:
How fortunate we were to wander in here after discovering that La Provence's "summer hours" mean that they're closed on Mondays and Tuesdays.  (Perhaps the owners actually go to Provence in the summers?)  We arrived at Tuba around 5:30 on a Tuesday, and were seated right away (certainly no need for reservations at that hour, though per other reviews, showing up later may warrant one).

Upon entering, we were stilled by the dark wood and red walls, a grounding effect that welcomed the enormous and hearty dinner we were about to consume.  Starting with the cold sampler plate (impressive in its fresh taste and interesting variety including dolmas, zucchini salad, eggplant salad, hummus etc), coupled with the delectable feta prawns, I must admit that we were already getting full before the entree we were sharing (per our server's recommendation) arrived.  

That stopped us not in the least, once our hearty mixed grill came.  Dang!  That's some good meat!  The Tuba mixed grill gave me a tromboner!!!  (So sorry, I couldn't help myself.)  Topped off with a fine Turkish wine, we were well pleased with our serendipitous find.  (Though not surprised at all when I came home and saw that Yelp loves Tuba.)  

Staff are lovely, service was timely, bathroom is clean.  I have only great honking noises for Tuba.
author: Ravena F.

description:
My friends and I decided to find a restaurant we wanted to try while in the city for a show, and we ended up here based on the location and wanting to try a different cuisine.  I called the restaurant first to confirm they had vegetarian options which they did.

I actually expected it to be a bit run down and more self service based on the sign (yeah, I was imagining a order at counter - wait to pick up order kind of place).  I was surprised to see a nice welcoming and cozy atmosphere when we finally got there.

It was not full by the time we were there, and that is surprising considering the food and service is exceptional!
