We decided to sit on the side with the pillows.  It was really comfortable considering the pillow was a good back support.

After getting some recommendations, we ordered the hot plate as the appetizer and ordered 3 vegetarian plates and one salmon dish.  We ended up taking the salmon dish with us to go as we ended up running a tad close to the time our show was about to start.  It wasn't their fault since we got there with about an hour to spare and had ordered appetizers.  It ended up to be too much food anyway, so that was a good thing.

They give you some amazing bread and spiced butter!  Again, the bread was AMAZING.  It was really flavorful and went absolutely well with the spiced butter they provided.   We probably got about 4 refills of it (talk about generous).  We got champagne also.  I decided to try the yogurt drink they had.  Boy was that rich.  It was definitely good for you, but it was really rich.  Quality for sure!  I had to share that with the table to finish the glass.  They were kind enough to bring small samples for each of my friends instead of me having to pour some into empty glasses.  That is really nice of them and thus, it goes to show how good our waitresses were.

The dishes included two different types of eggplant selection, a falafel  salad, and a salmon dish.  All the dishes except the salad came with rice and salad as sides.  Great portions, and I must say, the rice was delicious.  Not sure how they cooked it, but it went well with everything we had ordered.

After our show we ended up snacking on the left overs at one of the friend's place.  All in all, this was one heck of a find.  I will definitely go back here again.  Good food, great service, what more can you ask for.
author: Andrew N.

description: Let me start by saying that my 1 star rating represents our overall experience at the restaurant.  For the food, I would give it a 3.5.  The 1 star rating is based on how we were treated by the restaurant staff.  We had two members of our 4-person party cancel at the last minute due to illness.  When two of us showed up at the restaurant, the host was rude and angry that we had not notified him of our change in party size earlier.  Then he told us that we had only one hour to order and eat dinner before they needed our table back.
author: Jessica M.

description:
Reserved using Open Table option was easy and no issues for a Sat 6pm.  The place feels like another world and is great with the pillows on the bench and traditional hookah in the front window.  Small and cozy, not great for large groups over 10.
    Started with a pint of Stella, the beer selection was small, the wine more extensive.  Most of the menu I could not pronounce anything, but the staff did not seem offended at pointing and their constant explanation of what something was or how pronounce something was fun and educational.
1)combination cold meza mini appetizers enough for 4 was a small combo of all the appetizers was a great start.  This went great with the warm diagonally cut bread was just perfect and flavorful.
2)Special dinner entree was lamb shank with bulger (soft and gelatinous), soup and salad was killer good.  The best lamb I've even had, and I've even been to New Zealand known for their lamb.
3)Water and bread was always filled, we felt so welcome and waiters were attentive but not overbearing.
4) Dinner and drinks for two with tip under $100 with leftovers to take home is a great night.  We were in and out in less than an hour, but we did not feel rushed.
5) Great safe location, free street parking after 6pm Sat was not bad

I would go back and bring more friends to try all the variety was a bit overwhelming because everything sounded so good and hard to decide what to order.
author: David K.

description:
I don't even know where to start. I was excited for Turkish food, and I was starving. Unfortunately, the friend I was meeting here for dinner was incredibly late, so my mouth was watering as the servers brought dishes out left and right and none of them were for me.

I have to say I like the dark red walls, and the opulent bar. However, I have to say the artwork was NOT in the Turkish theme at all. Warm blocks of color (albeit nice to look at) do not remind me of Istanbul or Ankara, not even close.

Must-try on the menu:

Dolma - the usual delicious combo of rice, currants and other flavors wrapped in grape leaves.

Mixed Grill - great combo of 5 different kinds of meats: chicken, pork, lamb, beef, and something else I wasn't sure what it was but it was tasty. This dish is large enough for 2 if you're looking to share.

The Malbec selection was great....if you're into red wine, trust me when it comes to Malbec. However, this is the one thing on the menu I ordered that wasn't Turkish.
author: Alyssa G.

description: Way overpriced for what is it. Cut the prices in half and it would be a four star. Waiter women was also seemed a bit uninterested in her job.
author: Ali Y.

description: The food is divine! I loved every bit of it. Our appetizer, Meze Tabağı was incredible. The place looks modern, yet traditional. Great service as well.
author: Jasmina T.

description:
We called for a last minute reservation on Saturday, and were told that they could seat us at 6:00, which would give us one-half hour to get there.

The place is nicely decorated, the walls festively painted in orange.  Everybody there was super friendly. I ordered the special (catfish stuffed with crabmeat and bell peppers) and my partner ordered the salmon...both were delicious. The portions were fairly large...as we could have easily shared an entrée and an appetizer.  As much as we wanted to try a dessert...we were both just too stuffed.  The owner made a point to greet each table and asked how the food was.

We sat by the register...and the only drawback was the loud volume when the telephone rang.  Otherwise...definitely a place to check out if you haven't already.
author: L. L.

description: Had moussaka, lentil soup and shis tavuk. They boast their lentil soup is the best in town, and that claim is totally true! The service was kind of a let down though, the waitresses were all gathering around the same table, they didn't split our check 3 ways. But the food is just off the charts!
author: Manas A.

description: I came here for dinner with three others recently.  I really enjoyed the vegetarian appetizer sampler (Tuba Meze Tabagi)!  I shared the chicken kebabs (Tavuk Sis), which were good.  The owner brought out a few extra pieces of chicken on a separate plate and told us that the chef thought s/he had overcooked a few on the kebab.  However, the extra chicken, which was a nice gesture, turned out to be UNDERcooked and we didn't eat it.  One of the eggplant dishes (Sebzeli Patlican) was really tasty.  The bread they serve here is excellent, too! Friendly service; seems family-run.
author: micaela r.

description:
I was pleasantly surprised - this is definitely a great Turkish restaurant, and a nice upscale alternative to the cheap places in the Loin.  I wouldn't have found this place but for Groupon, and I'm glad I did.

Service was stellar.  I mean, absolutely outstanding.  Our server was incredibly warm, friendly and helpful, but not intrusive.  The soft, warm bread and herb butter were a nice start.  Lentil soup was perfect.  My manti was pretty standard - not exciting but I wasn't really expecting it to be, I just wanted manti, and I got it.  The mixed grill kebab sampler was. just. delicious.  Probably the best lamb I've had in years - moist, tender, and well-seasoned.  The chicken was standard.  The kofte kebab and adana kebab were perfect.  The accompanying rice was fluffy and delicious.

The kunafa house special dessert was SO GOOD.  It's not like the kunafa I've previously had which is drier and more pastry-like (still delicious) - here, it's warm, layered with cheese, and dripping with honey.  Add a cup of Turkish coffee and you've got one of the best dessert experiences ever, hands down.
author: Riya K.

description: This Turk loves this place. It's the best Turkish food in the city by a long shot. All the mezes and the kebabs I've tried have been delicious.
author: Evren O.

description: Came in on Friday as a last minute dinner option and had a great time.  The staff was warm and curious and made great suggestions.  The owner was involved and handed up two fantastic glasses of wine while we waited an extra ten minutes while our table was prepared.  And the food was fantastic.  I have passed this place 100 times driving and so glad we stopped.  Try the stuffed eggplant.  Amazing.
author: brett b.

description: We absolutely loved the food here! The dishes were authentic and perfectly cooked. The owner and the server were both very friendly and made us feel right at home. The restaurant was surprisingly crowded on a weeknight, so I recommend reservations!
author: Diana G.

description: Great Mediterranean food and was able to find lots of vegetarian options.
author: Kara L.

description:
Good signs were that there were all Turkish people eating there with us.  We only ordered the sampler platter had so many interesting new things. Not just the typical hummus baba ganoush etc. Super delicious, unique and very fresh.

The decor is cozy clean and cute and kind of DIY homey.
author: Melanie C.

description: Lovely restaurant serving family recipes.  I especially loved the mezze platter.  All of the staff was very friendly and helpful offering suggestions on what to order and knowledgeable about the Turkish wines on the menu.  I was there with a few friends and everything we ordered was delicious.
author: Allison K.

description:
Great restaurant - been here twice. The send time because i was obsessing and craving for the food :) 

The first time we came here with friends and we ordered couple of the dips (yogurt dips are my fav and the one in tuba is delish), and shared the mousakka (they have a vegetarian one) with my friend. Its so rich and with the rice and yogurt dip, i couldn't ask for anything more. The meat eaters tried the lamb and chicken kebabs and nobody at the table was complaining.

When i go to restaurants I try to have wines from the region of the restaurant and i did here too, but it was too full bodied (and earthy) for my taste, but that's just a personal thing. 

The service was amazing, both times. very friendly, great suggestions.

But the highlight - kanefe! we tried to share it amongst 4 people the first time. Its a good thing, we didn't jump into a fight over that dessert. IT was incredible! 

ps: the dessert was the obsession, but the rest of the food holds up very well too.
author: Sapna E.

description: Had a delightful meal at Tuba with great wine and truly excellent service.  The salmon was beyond delicious and the chicken kabob to die for.  We had a zucchini patty that defies description and a chocolate Creme Brulee that was the perfect finale to a lovely dinner in a quiet, peaceful and caring place.  I cannot recommend  this restaurant highly enough for a  relaxed,, excellent dining experience
author: Lynn Ruth M.

description: Great food, reasonable portion sizes, and incredible service.
author: Rex C.

description: My friend and I really enjoyed our meal here. We had no expectations of what was in store aside from being able to order a variety of hearty dishes, so we dove into each with fervor. Fortunately, the prices are reasonable. I'm confident in recommending anything on the menu that appeals to you. The service was quick, knowledgeable, and polite.
author: Mike H.

description: Incredible service, very friendly- people you'd want to invite to a dinner party. I am gluten free and this spot has a number of excellent options. Dolma are my favorite. I could eat those as a meal alone. Their falafel is also gluten free and is delicious. The environment is casual and charming. A great spot for a date or a small group of friends.  You can't go wrong here!
author: karen h.

description:
I can't help but give Tuba 5 stars. Came here last night and still thinking about how delicious everything was. 
My b/f and I love going out in the Mission and this place happened to have a reservation open at 8pm on a Friday so we snagged it.  
We started with the Cevizli Ezme, a cold Meze that is basically a delicious spread with crushed/pureed walnuts, red peppers, garlic, olive oil etc. They bring you endless amounts of warm wonderful bread with olives, feta cheese, and herbed butter. The Cevizli Ezme was so very flavorful and spiced perfectly. I could have been content just dipping my bread in that alone all night. 
We also ordered the crab cakes (I'm not sure how much of a Turkish dish that is) although still it was cooked just right, again very flavorful and came on top of a bed of greens that had a nice light dressing with hints of mint in it.
We shared a main course called the Manti which was dumplings with garlic yogurt sauce and mint. Again, it was perfect and flavored so perfectly. 
We were so content and full and not ready to move yet we sat and stayed and had another drink. The waitress even got to me try some Turkish wine that was also really good (comparable to a Malbec). 
The waitress and owner were very friendly, the atmosphere is cozy but casual enough and their prices are extremely reasonable. Above all the food was delicious and full of flavor. I'm really looking forward to coming back!
author: Kristina P.

description: Food was decent, nothing extraordinary. Service was not super attentive or accomodating...amature waitstaff.
author: Joshua S.

description:
The review average place for this is the reason why I don't *really* use Yelp anymore to gauge the quality of restaurants.  

Just think about it, how can an extremely mediocre restaurant with subpar food and service compete with the best of SF (who also have 4-star reviews)?  

On the good side, food was clean (as opposed to dirty) and the portions were huge.  But the quality of flavors was so boring that I can barely recall what I ordered.  I was especially disappointed because I live 3 blocks away and am married to a "Middle Eastern" - so this had the potential of becoming a staple for us.

Definitely would choose Old Jerusalem on Mission *any* day, for the price, authenticity, and food.  

Tuba feels like a hack of a restaurant conceived by a rich landlord who doesn't truly care about food.  Unfortunately, there are quite a few of these in the city.
author: Margot L.

description: This is hands-down the best Turkish food I've ever eaten. Every detail of every dish -- and I ate many of them -- exceeded my expectations. The atmosphere and the service were also stellar. I can't recommend Tuba highly enough. Truly a delight to eat there.
author: Avi T.

description: Absolutely fabulous! My stomach hasn't been this happy since I was actually traveling in Greece and Turkey. The service was quite good too, though to be honest I was too distracted by the delicious food to really notice.
author: Sarah J.

description:
I really enjoyed this restaurant. I thought the baked salmon rocked. I'm usually a meat eater and gave it up for Lent + a few more weeks.

I probably would have never gotten the baked stuffed salmon, but I'm so happy I did. It was amazingly juicy and I think if anyone gets it, they will enjoy it (beware it is buttery, this is probably why I really enjoyed it :).....)
author: Eric A.

description: Nice, quiet atmosphere. Great price. Really delicious and unique food.
author: Alexei A.

description: Picked this date night destination and it turned out wonderful. The service was extremely warm and welcoming. I thought the way they talked about their special with the placard on the table was a little lame, not sure if that's normal. The cold appetizer platter was so tasty, highly recommended!
author: Anant A.

description:
Came here with a group of friends.  We ordered several items to share: for appetizers, the mixed cold and the mixed hot plates, two types of salad, the salmon dish, beyti andana (ground sirloin and lamb wrapped in lavash bread served with tomato sauce and yogurt) and the mixed grill plate (sampling of all the meats).

If it's your first time trying Turkish food, i recommend the mixed plates that the have--it's a great way to sample a little of everything.  It was all delicious although I would say the salmon was nothing special.  It was almost like creamed spinach over salmon.  Have to say that they have excellent presentation.

Only complaint would have to be how close all he chairs were, on one table and then from table to table.  It was also quite warm inside, but fortunately cooled down after the sun went down.
author: Christopher W.

description:
My husband and I had a groupon for this place, and after tonight, I'm definitely got we got it and took the time to try it out! 

The waitress was friendly, but not the intrusive friendly type -- so you were well taken care of without being disturbed more often then needed.

The food came out quickly. As an appetizer,  we shared "Mücver" ("pan fried zucchini patties with fresh dill")  which were really good. The portion was also generous and the plating -- elegant. 

Then almost immediately, we got our main meals. I had the lamb shish kebab, while my husband had the kofte kebab. Both were really tasty. I personally thought my choice was nicer, but the kofte kebab had more meat. Both were served with some nice rice and veggies. All of the food was fresh. And again, for those who care about aesthetics: plating was once more elegant. 

This might not be the best of the best in San Fran (haven't tried that many Turkish restaurants in the city though I have experience with this type of food), but I don't have a single complaint, and we were really pleased, so I'm giving it a full 5 stars. 

PS: prices are very reasonable.
author: Raymonde T.

description:
Tuba is an elegant yet cozy little haunt for good, reliable Mediterranean food.  I had the lamb chops here and they were amazing.  Finger-sucking good!  Probably the best I've had in a while.  

The portions are generous, the prices reasonable, and the service is decent - it's a perfect place to bring a date.  But definitely don't bring more than two - this place really is on the smaller side.
author: Kira K.

description: When the rest of the mission is busy, Tuba is here to take care of our Mediterranean needs. Best hummus in town.
author: Rob S.

description:
My husband keeps telling me "I want to go back there."  And its because this place is amazing!  The portions are huge and deiicious, the ambiance is very inviting and the staff is friendly.  I made a reservation in advance because I hear it can get crowded and even on a Wednesday night, it can fill up by 8pm.  

I would recommend the Vegetarian Moussaka.  Yum!
author: Tara T.

description:
I was craving some Mediterranean, but as a vegetarian, I'm usually relegated to falafels and Greek Salad.  So when I saw that the menu in Tuba had some unique options, my friend and I headed over for a meal.

Location is great:  It's in the non-sketchy part of Mission, about a 5-10 minute walk from Bart and major bus lines.  Very pleasant walk after dinner amidst pretty houses.  It's a little quiet, so maybe parking is easier here, but my car is a Muni pass, so I wouldn't know.

Ambiance: It is pleasant inside.  The decor isn't really Turkish, but is nice.  A great date location.  Waitresses were extremely friendly.

Food:  YES!  They give everyone complimentary bread with Turkish-seasoned butter, and it was great!  My friend and I shared a zucchini yogurt appetizer (Kabak Ezme), which I had never tasted before and was so, so good!   We then shared 2 entrees:  the stuffed eggplant and the moussaka (their version is vegetarian!).  Both entrees were AWESOME and portion sizes were good - they came with basmati rice and salad.  

We really wanted dessert but we didn't stop eating in time and were just too full.  But the sweet cheese stuffed phyllo w/ honey and nuts sounds amazing!

Total cost was $42 w/ tax and tip.  Definitely planning to go back!
author: Rani V.

description:
Cozy/crowded spot. We had dinner here on a Saturday night when we couldn't really agree on what to eat. Despite our reservation, we had to wait a while because it was absolutely packed. We had the sigara boregi (fried feta cheese) to start, he had the kofte kebab and I had the lamb shish kebab. Overall, good sized portions and pretty tasty. The bf commented that the kofte was not as good as two usual places he likes to frequent on the peninsula, but I still thought my lamb hit the spot. 

The main things I did not particularly enjoy were 1) it was so crowded, I was sitting closer to the woman next to me on the banquette than my dining companion (her conversation wasn't THAT interesting either), 2) it was so loud that I felt like I had to scream to have my own conversation (the screaming child across the room fit right in!). I could see me returning if I lived in the neighborhood because I did like the food, but likely won't bother.
author: Nora G.

description:
Meh 

I used my groupon to check out this new venue. I was very underwhelmed with the service. The host and server weren't really that friendly at all. Weird considering there weren't make people there. 

We ordered the hot sample platter - Everything was fried and just meh.. The hummus on the other hand was delicious. 

I'll most likely not come back but it was fun to try a new place.
author: Monica S.

description: Excellent food - absolutely the best mediterranean food I have had in the city.  The prices are very reasonable, and we had a great time on our anniversary.
author: Priya R.

description:
Tuba fills the gap as an intermediary option between hole in the wall and spendy splurge restaurants. It is comfortable with enough elbow room and surprisingly pleasant ambiance. There's a nice buzz about the room but you don't feel like they are rushing to turn your table. 

Two lady friends and I decided to go with an array of appetizers and skip the less interesting entrees. We started with the Tuba cold platter and also split the hot platter and creamy indulgent feta prawns. This was quite the bounty to match a round of Turkish white wines by the glass and a bottle of budget-friendly sauvignon blanc. I'm a sucker for the lemony, tahini-rich, olive oil, garlic, tomato, and eggplant flavors of the Mediterranean, so I quite enjoyed our meal. The mezze heavy small plates are give you an opportunity to taste a lot of items and share with friends.
author: Candice L.

description:
We went here because our Groupon was about to expire. Had been meaning to try it for a while after reading some nice things about the place. 

We had the Moussaka and the Stuffed Eggplant. Both dishes were really tasty. However, we've never been to Turkey, so we're not sure of the authenticity, or lack thereof, that others on Yelp are complaining about. 

The unfortunate thing is that despite our liking the food here, we can only give the restaurant 3 stars. The woman at the front with the long curly hair who acted as our hostess and later as our waitress was quite rude. 

From the moment we arrived she did not greet us in a friendly manner. I told her our party size and she sniped back about whether we had a reservation. I told her no, and she acted like I was being a lot of trouble about it. The place was 60% empty at that point, but I get that others may have made reservations. If you're busy, it's fine, let me know and we'll find some other place that needs the business. She had the same attitude upon taking our order and taking the Groupon from us, even though we ended up tipping well on the pre-Groupon bill. 

They eventually accommodated us at a smaller table all the way at the back right next to the kitchen, even though there was a perfect sized table at the front window where it was much cooler. It was probably 88 degrees or so inside towards the back. 

There was a gentleman who served us our food and his attitude was just fine. They had set our table with 1 place setting, one napkin and knife, and one napkin. We let him know about the mistake when he presented our food and he was polite about it and got us what we needed right away.

If I'm paying $13 for half an eggplant with some diced vegetables mixed in, please be nice to me. Based on the service we received from this individual I don't think I would go back just due to the chance she would wait on us again.
author: aaron f.

description: Lamb kabobs were delicious, juicy, tender. Unfortunately for me, so was the rice so I gobbled it up.  Hubby had lamb chops (marinated for 3 days - or something similar to this) and he LOVED them. I wish the portions had been a bit bigger - for the price.  Definitely will go here again.
author: SteveAndDena E.

description: Really great ambiance and food. Very homey feel and the service was superb. We went on kind of a slower night, and so they were able to give us top shelf service. Great corkage fee too! Overall a great value.
author: Alex S.

description:
First (and reflexively), I struggled whether to award the place 4-stars based on frantic annoyance at being misdirected and then having my damn smartphone 'tard out on me.  Or considering my taste buds dulled by the onset of a miserable cold. In the end, my 4-stars standard won out (and you can't give a half-star in yelp). The basics:  Well-prepared Turkish food (not the original Morrocan I craved, perhaps another ding factor....) served quickly;  a modest but well-thought out wine list (Yummy Russian River Pinot by the glass); lovely, inviting space made for a warm tonic to the chilly night.  

The mezzas are yummy. The felafel is wonderfully green and crispy, and, best of all, served wide and round, a hallmark of handmade not prepackaged, and well-crisped.  My mis-drecting dining companion had a yummy set of vegetarian dishes: Ezme (crushed walnuts, pepper paste, et al) that complemented the felafel, and the Musakka.  My lamb kabobs were cooked to charbroiled perfection (moist).  The conversation was pleasant (except for the obnoxious indie-cred discussion by the table of mission hipsters.... When will these folks wither away?).

In addition to the tasty food, the wait staff (hostess and waitress) were attentive and prompt.  The space is small enough that on busy nights it could fill up quickly, but the two handled the smallish crowd deftly.

I will definitely be heading back, if only to indulge in the Künefe, the oft-mentioned phyllo-cheese pastry dish.
author: philip c.

description: The best Turkish food in the whole of the USA. My mother-in-law is from Turkey and we stop at every Turkish restaurant when we travel. This is by far the best we've had. Stuffed falafel in the salad was the perfect consistency; the mucver was crispy on the outside & deliciously soft inside; doner kebab was cooked nice & tender, and the beyti Adana had crispy, flaky lavash bread wrapped around the meat--original & delicious. Wish we lived in San Francisco--what a find!
author: ACM M.

description:
Tuba was a solid, well-crafted Turkish restaurant experience. I came with a friend of mine and we used a groupon to order and share a few plates. Being Turkish myself, I jumped on the menu to try and get a variety of things so we could figure out what was best.

The mucver (mooj-vare) was fantastic. For those who don't know, it's essentially zucchini and other random green vegetables mashed together and fried into a ball using an egg batter that's a little heavy on the dill. It reminded of me aunt's cooking and it might have actually been the highlight of the meal!

We then had the hunkar begendi (bay-end-ee), which was a creamy pile of eggplant mush, heavy on garlic, with pieces of lamb in it. If you like eggplant, you should definitely get this dish. If you don't, avoid it all costs. Because you're really just eating delicious eggplant mush.

Last, we had the mixed grill, which had a chicken kebab, lamb kebab, kofte kebab, adana kebab, and the world's tiniest single lamb chop. The tiny lamb chop of good, the kofte kebab standard, and the chicken/lamb kebab forgettable (as they usually are most everywhere). That said, the adana kebab was awesome. Really spicy all the way through the meat, flavorful, cooked just right. I'd go back here just for more adana kebab. Awesome.

The services was Turkish-friendly and they made ice tea out of Turkish tea, which is why I was on a caffeine high until 2am. Overall, this might be the best Turkish restaurant in San Francisco right now.
author: Tolga E.

description: Phenomenal experience overall and a ScoutMob discount to boot! Kept it simple with a falafel salad, which was great to share and scrumptious with feta filled falafel. Main entree was the lamb kebob, which the waiter claimed were the "best in the Bay" -- and they were delicious: seared and cooked medium, they cut like steak and didn't have anything really "lamby" about them. Finished off with oven-baked rice pudding: light and a perfect pallet cleaner. Not only was the food amazing, but the service was amazing; attentive and very quick.
author: Cristina M.

description:
I loved this restaurant. Had never heard anything about it-saw an Opentable 1000 restaurant score, and figured that I might as well try something new. (How many times can you go back to Luna Park?)

The flatbread is off the charts good. Soft, chewy with wonderful accompaniments of sundried pesto butter and feta. 

I ordered two mezes: a falafel/hummus plate and the feta cheese and potato phyllo rolls. So good and filling. It is the perfect place to get soul warming food on a cold, wet San Francisco summer evening.

 The portions are HUGE. I had ended up taking back most of itI was stuffed after eating one falafel patty, a side salad and one phyllo roll. 

.My husband ordered the lentil soup, which is purported to be best in San Francisco and the chicken. He was stuffed too. He also had a beer.

Final price tag: $50 for everything. Amazing quality of food and great portions. Guess what I am eating on Sunday night?
author: Peggy B.

description: The food was totally delicious!  Who knew lentil soup could taste so good?  I ordered the vegan eggplant entrée, which was totally scrumptious.  The service was fabulous too!
author: Terry F.

description:
I understand some of the criticism here about service, but not really the complaints about the food. We had a large party (7 people) on a Friday night, and they took our reservation...but when we got to the restaurant they hadn't prepared for us to come and had to ask another table of two to move so that we could be accommodated. Not great planning on their part, but after waiting 15 minutes it worked out.

After that, the service and food were top-notch. I loved the feta cheese rolls which were delicious, and we had the server select a couple of meat and veggie options for us to split family-style. The spicy lamb was amazing, as was the moussaka with eggplant.

www.restaurant.com offers $100 for $50 coupons for this place (I think maybe other options too) so we got a really sweet deal when it came down to splitting the bill. The BYOB thing helped too, obviously, but that probably won't last once they get a license.

All in all, I would highly recommend this place, but maybe would recommend going with a smaller group.
author: Hannah L.

description: This is a great restaurant.  The food was good, the service was friendly and prompt.  Everyone enjoyed their meals and the experience.  I had the lamb shank price fix and it was perfect.  I would definitely recommend this restaurant.
author: Jeff B.

description:
I am surprised to see the high reviews here.  The place has potential, but I'm not rating on that.  The restaurant was decently designed and service started out well, but food should be the ulitimate driver for this rating.  While it's great that you can bring your own wine for now, the food was good but not out of this world, nothing to be excited about necessarily.  There were two of us and our order took a really long time.  Our appetizer came out first and was cold - they gladly took it back (but don't they check it before it goes out?).  It took about another 30 minutes or so to see our entrees.  While our server was very kind and apologetic, it ruined the experience.  We observed other parties who got there after us had both their apps and entrees served. Perhaps they are working out those kinks, but seems to be a trend as seen in the other reviews.  

It's really too bad that this was our first impression as we went in not having high expectations to begin with, only to have a nice meal with good service.  Not sure I will try this place again. Bummer.
author: Adrian N.

description:
Lamb shish was delicious. I tried also "icli kofte" but its shell was so thick and have less ground beef. I wish I drunk Raki, a traditional drink of Turkey, but it wasn't in the menu. 

The restaurant had kind staff. The service was fast. Main menu was awesome. It was worth to try.
author: Irfan K.

description:
Stumbled onto this place by accident, I was supposed to go to another latin place that was booked and walked and walked in search of sushi then saw this place, yelped it and decided to take a chance.
Great ambiance, good service and the prices were not bad given the portions you get.
We were a party of three and ordered hummus, falafels, and the kofte for apetizers, all three were yummy and came out with the entrees just like we asked.
For entrees we had the shrimp kebabs, mixed grill kebabs and the lamb chops, ohhh boy, each platter was delicious, tender, juicy and flavorful.
Had a glass of wine which was just perfect with the food, at the end we were all stuffed and still had some food to go which we devoured the next morning.
Overall the place exceeded expectations and will return when I visit the city again, yum, I am hungry again!
author: M J.

description:
Over the past 4 years of living in the City I've had the opportunity to try cuisines from all corners, and Turkish always finishes on the top of my list.  This is why I was excited to hear about this restaurant opening so close to my home. I made my first visit to Tuba a few nights after it opened as the third wheel to a couple that I'm friends with, and without a doubt, will be my go-to place when I'm craving some Turkish fare.

The atmosphere was warm and inviting with decorations one could tell that some extra attention and care had been taken.   Our starters which we shared were the Ezme (my favorite) and a falafel salad.  The falafel was warm and crisp on the outside, but not dried out, and had a bit of melting goat cheese in the middle, a nice touch.

My main course was the lamb chops which were grilled amazingly.  I also shared a little of an eggplant dish that I can't remember the name of.  I had Irmik for dessert.  It was a warm treat of pine nuts sauteed in butter mixed with cinnamon and semolina, all topped with a little vanilla ice cream. The dessert I ate was new to me and pretty good, but at that point I was already full.  Be careful not to fill up and overdo it on the unlimited bread they'll offer to bring you.  I skipped the Turkish coffee since I was headed to SFO for a red eye that night, but left Tuba more than satisfied and excited to return.

Once their liquor license is approved, it can only get better when they can serve some nice selections from Kavaklidere, or an Efes in a frosty glass.
author: Aaron D.

description: Basic Turkish restaurant done right. The food is well cooked with very good but not extraordinary flair. Service was very helpful. Plentiful Turkish wine selection but decent selection from other areas that complement the meal well.
author: Ed r.

description: We shared two delicious appetizers and both had great entrees. We were paralyzed a bit about the variety on the menu (not huge, just a great range of dishes). It all sounded wonderful. The also have have Turkish beer and wines. I had a Turkish Syrah that was very good. The service was friendly, funny, and engaging - but not hovering or bothersome. We will be back the next time work takes me into the city.
author: Chris T.

description: Tuba is an incredible spot for dinner! I highly recommend it. I found out about Tuba on OpenTable and happily booked a reservation when I saw the high star rating and the 1000 dining point bonus. Everything we had was delicious, especially the Musakka (that dish is literally to die for... the sauce was divine). The service was great as well. The staff was super attentive and friendly. We will definitely be back in the near future!
author: Tessa P.

description:
Excellent food with tons of veggie options. We ordered the cold appetizer platter and the falafel salad, and everything was super tasty. The food portions are big and we were super stuffed by the end of the night.

The ambience was nice, service was top-notch and everyone was very friendly. Excellent value for your money. I am definitely coming back and would love to try the other dishes on their menu. 

The restaurant got full very fast and I will recommend making reservations if you don't want to wait.
author: Pratima A.

description: I go back and back and back to this place because the food is SO good and the owners are SO nice.  This is the type of comfort food neighborhood restaurant that I was searching for and finally found.  Oh, and I recently discovered the Chocolate Pyramid dessert.  I'm not sure how Turkish it is, but, frankly, who cares . . . it is soooooo good!
author: D H.

description: I was introduced to this wonderful restaurant by a friend. It has a warm atmosphere and yummy food. Berk, the host, is warm and welcoming. We had a sampling of mezes with beer and wine, followed by a lamb kebab, moist and rare, and a Mediterranean salad, crisp and refreshing.
author: Hector L.

description: I've never had a bad meal here.  pretty much everything on their menu is worthy.  there was this one time where i didn't care for one of the three dishes we had ordered, but i can't seem to recall what that dish was.  it wasn't terrible, just not up to snuff for that restaurant.  with that being said, you've got about a 95% chance of having an excellent meal.
author: Terri M.

description: I love Tuba for a quiet weeknight dinner.  Their musakka is out of this world, thinly-sliced eggplant, zucchini, potatoes, and squash with a not-too-heavy bechamel sauce on top.  Fresh salad and rice on the side (not to mention delicious flatbread to start) means I can usually only eat about half the dish on my own.  Friendly service and a warm, cozy atmosphere too!
author: Heidi D.

description:
Merhaba Tuba! Welcome to my neighborhood; I've been waiting for you for soooo long!

I can't begin to describe how excited I am about this place. When people ask me what I miss about Turkey (I moved to the US in 1994), my answer  always begins with the same duo: "I miss the Aegean Sea and I miss the food." I always add that I also miss Turkish hospitality. 

Well. 

The Aegean Sea remains far away, but Tuba brings to my adopted home, the Mission, both the food and the hospitality that I'd been missing. 

Reservations (in response to an earlier review): I made reservations on Opentable.com, and upon arriving at the restaurant (a little after 6 pm--I was rushing to get to a show that night), I realized I didn't need to. The place was empty when I arrived. I think more people began coming in around 6:30 or so. By the time I left the restaurant around 7:30 pm, the restaurant was full, but there were still tables available. My suggestion: if you can, use Opentable.com -- it's handy, has an iPhone app, and you get credit the more you use it.  

Hospitality: My partner-in-crime wasn't there when I arrived at Tuba, so I stood there for a second, looking at the menu. The owner immediately noticed me and welcomed me in. As soon as I sat down, he asked if I would like some tea or coffee while I waited. We chatted a bit about his restaurant, and because he doesn't have his liquor license yet, he encouraged me to bring my own from the store at the end of the block if I needed some beer or wine with my meal. He mentioned he expects to get his license in the next two weeks (this was about a week ago). He was happy to provide a corkscrew or a bottle opener and glasses for us. Such a warm person. I immediately felt at home in this space, and getting to speak in Turkish with him was an added bonus. 

The food: My ultimate test of authenticity is the dolma. I can walk into a Middle Eastern café, take one look at the dolmas, and be able to tell whether they're from a can or homemade (sorry to say, folks, most of the time, they're from a can). A restaurant, of course, is different. I asked our waiter if they were homemade just in case, and they were...and they were almost as good as grandma's. Almost. My partner-in-crime, who apparently doesn't usually like dolma, ate all of his, so there you go. 

The other appetizers we got were the sigara börek and ezme (the regular kind, not the zucchini kind). The börek was great (careful with your first bite--it's hot!), and the ezme was out of this world. We tried in vain to stop ourselves from spreading the ezme on the delicious pide (not pita) bread so we didn't get too full. 

Well, we did get too full, and we weren't so hungry at 6 pm to begin with. Fortunately, we had ordered the mixed grill to share (the one-person version rather than the mixed grill for two). It came with lamb chop (fantastic!), chicken kebab, shish kebab, adana kebab, rice, and veggies (I think I'm forgetting one more kind of kebab on there). It was plenty of food for both of us after all the appetizers, and yet another affirmation that Oh. Yes. I do looooove meat on a skewer. 

With no room for dessert, I had to skip the irmik helvasi that I was looking forward to sampling. Next time! 

Just thinking about the menu makes my mouth water. There's so much variety and deliciousness on that menu that I just can't wait to return! 

Bonus points for Tuba: 
1. As someone who learned English as a second language, and who is now an English teacher, I have an instinctive habit of recognizing typos and grammatical errors on menus, especially when they're not American restaurants. I saw no errors on Tuba's menu. 
2. Wine-red walls always make me feel at home...so do beautiful dark wood furniture.
author: Yakamoz S.

description:
Warm goat cheese in falafel?  On a salad with avocado dressing?  

Shut the front door.

This place was super yummy and the portions are pretty big.   How could you go wrong?  Answer: you can't.
author: Renee D.

description: We ordered the Beyti Adana & Mixed Grill Entree, both were amazing and succulent! Service, ambiance were outstanding, and you can walk to the restaurant from bart though it is a couple blocks away.  Check out the pictures of the food on yelp to get those mouths watering!  Will definitely be back again!
author: Nazli P.

description: The service at Tuba was exceptional. The staff was warm and welcoming. The food was delicious. Wonderful dining experience. Highly recommend.
author: Jane B.

description:
I lived around the corner from this place for an entire year about two years ago and never even knew it was there.  The new owner has had the business for 9 months now and is starting to drum up some much-needed advertising for the place.
The restaurant is nicely decorated and comfortable.  All of the staff were extremely nice and accommodating. The food was not only delicious but the plates resembled works of art; the food looked almost too good to eat!  There are plenty of items on the menu that are suitable for everyone: vegans, veggies and meat-eaters alike.
Food is moderately priced and the portions are sizable.  My only regret about coming is having to leave.
author: Ashley T.

description:
Just came home from our first meal at Tuba and I am still savoring the delicious flavors of the authentic Turkish food. The service is excellent:  we were greeted by the host himself and because it was still early and the restaurant hadn't yet filled up for the evening (it did!) we had a nice chat with him about Turkey (we've been there twice) and the extensive cuisine it boasts. The service was fine without being intrusive, and the ambience of the restaurant felt authentic. 

We asked our server for recommendations, and the suggestions did not disappoint, starting with the Turkish white wine, a house-made lemonade, and the large plate of cold mezes.  There were three of us, so we selected three main courses, each of which was delicious.  I can't remember their names, but one was a plate of small dumplings stuffed with ground beef, another was grilled shrimp with asparagus.  While Turkish food borrows from many cuisines, the flavors here were interesting and unique.  Definitely a be-back for us!
author: NOMIE M.

description: All around excellent. We had 3 of the cold appetizers. All fresh, perfectly spiced, Mediterranean-diet healthy. Chicken kebab succulent, beautiful. Service excellent. Prices reasonable.
author: Bib G.

description: First of all, location: far enough from Valencia to find parking.  In fact, we found street parking within two blocks. Ambiance: warm and welcoming. Service: impeccable. They cleared our silverware midway and wiped our table before dessert.  Dishes: we ordered ezme (crushed walnuts, pepper paste, etc.), lentil soup, moussaka, beyti adana (grilled lamb wrapped in lavash with yogurt and grilled pepper), and for dessert, kiinefe (delicious), Turkish coffee, and Turkish tea.  Each dish was well prepared and attractively presented.  The complimentary bread was served warm with  spicy butter/olives/feta cheese. We loved the decor of deep red walls, hanging lights, splashy abstract paintings, and unusually colorful salt and pepper shakers.  This is a perfect place for a date on a Friday night.
author: Liana T.

description: Excellent Turkish food = TUBA!! Jay helped me  put together a menu for my husband's birthday. Everything was yummy, tasty and flavorful.  We had the cold and hot platters, crab cakes (heaven), lamb chops-tender, juicy and gone in 10 mins, Adana kebab-another favorite and for dessert freshly made,  baklava- I finish 1/3 of the tray.  I would definitely order from Tuba again for parties and come back to dine to experience the great service from Jay and excellent food.
author: Cyn F.

description:
Really cozy spot, in a great neighborhood, the waitresses are awesome! The food, although copious, is really average, decent as a whole but nothing great. For example the köftes are delicious but too charbroiled which overpowers the taste unfortunately. If you aren't familiar w/ Turkish food, than this place is great, for aficionados like myself, not a hit. 
3*
author: M S.

description:
At some point I think most frequent Yelper foodies have a crisis of confidence. It usually happens in the company of others. Perhaps you've just launched into a sotto voice diatribe about how not awesome the mole/falafel/burger/hip food of the moment you ordered is. It could be after a snooty aside about the played out decor or the indifferent service. The critical wheels of your brain are well lubricated with 30 weight haterade and you're already salivating over the next Yelp bomb you'll drop perhaps as soon as right then if you can punch out something appropriately pithy on your ninjaphone. 

You stop and wonder if your urge to disassemble your dining experience is, itself, crapping on your dining experience or (sometimes more importantly) the experience of your homies. 

Well, I'm here to say "funk that!" Top off the pretty hate machine with another quart of vitriolade and let it rip. Like I'm about to. 

The oh-so-soon to be missus wanted to give these guys 1 star. We could go with 1.5 stars, let's call it that. We'll round up to 2 thanks to our $25 of flat, unseasoned Turkish food for $12 Groupon and the two glasses of wine they comped us for the 52 minute wait between our salad and main courses. 

This place is pricey homes and doesn't really show out with anything to set it above your corner schwarma shop. In fact, we both ranked it a solid cut below the late night kabob cart (see NYC). Why? Lack of flavor! 

Dings 
- regular bread at the table - weird. Nothing specifically wrong with it but we were expecting pita and it didn't quite jive with the food. 
- cold dip thing tasted like... hmm, mostly nothing 
- Sheppard's salad was basically a Greek salad but ended up being a LOT of cucumbers, a few bits of tomato, red onion, 4 olives, and some parsley. 
- manti pasta was uber watery, bland, and chef boy-r-dee tasting with little or no sauce or taste beyond general ground beef 
- kabob sampler was the highlight, everything well cooked but somewhat under seasoned (a recurring theme)

The worst gripes were the total lack of communication in the service. Almost an hour between salad and mains without any kind of communication in the interim sucks. After a few attempts to get information on when we could expect our food we were met with confusion ("did you get your salad yet?") and then lame excuses ("the pasta takes a long time to cook" what pasta takes an hour to cook?). 

Every restaurant can have bad kitchen nights and this might have been one of them. Our server did her best to recover and was gracious and apologetic but the stand out failure of our meal was how often we had to reach for the salt and pepper shakers just to make the food passable. 

I might expect that at a steak house but at a Turkish restaurant? I know a few things about Middle Eastern food and one of them is that lack of flavor and seasoning is not usually an issue. If I'm going to pay double what I'd pay at Truly Mediterranean I would like it to be at least slightly better as opposed to much worse. 

Remember kids, honesty goes both ways.  So don't fear to speak your mind.
author: Milk N.

description:
Tuba occupies a space which has been the site of many a failed restaurant since I've lived in the neighborhood. However, judging from their food, service and ambiance -- and the fact that they've been continually busy since opening a few months ago -- I'm confident Tuba will be around for a while.

The Mücver, pan fried zucchini patties with fresh dill, are superb, as is the Musakka, which I was thrilled to learn is vegetarian. The Patlican Salatasi -- grilled eggplant puree with bell pepper, tomato, garlic -- is also excellent. I was too full to try dessert (portions are substantial), but I will definitely be back to sample them.

Service is deft, friendly and welcoming, and they've totally transformed the space; it's warm, inviting and beautiful.

I smell a hit.
author: The Other Jeff A.

description:
I don't understand why this place has such great reviews. Maybe it was the specific dishes we ordered, but it was absolutely mediocre at best. The lamb kebobs were dry, lifeless and rubbery.

Saving grace? The semolia halvesi was decent. Oh and the prosecco bottle :)

Also, the service was awful! We waited nearly 45 minutes, first for our server to arrive, and then for our food to arrive because "the kitchen lost your order". To be fair, the server was very sweet and apologized for the mix-up.
author: Ishita G.

description: We found this place thanks to Yelp during a trip to the city. What a gem - small and intimate yet still friendly and deeeelicious. The wait staff was so kind, every single person went out of their way to make sure we were enjoying the experience. The appetizers, entrees, desserts, and coffees - all first rate. Thanks for the great night out!
author: Deanna W.

description:
When you tell the server multiple times that you're allergic to chilies, peppers, and all manner of spicy food, they should be able to recommend a safe option from the menu. Instead, I was told they could make anything without spices. So I ordered the Kafte Kebab... And it was definitely too hot for me when it arrived. I suspect it had red pepper or cayenne, but I couldn't tell for certain. :( This is why I give four stars instead of five.

Fortunately one of my dining companions had ordered the "Stuffed Salmon with fume sauce over rice," and he was eying my kebab with entree envy, so we switched plates. This was one of the most fantastic Salmon dishes I've ever had the pleasure of eating. It's certainly not Turkish (I spent a month in Turkey and don't recall this dish being part of any traditional Turkish menu), but it's a nice option when you're struggling to communicate a food allergy in an ethnic setting.

The appetizers, including the hummus and fried feta cheese, were delicious, as was the chocolate cake I had for desert. I would highly recommend Tuba to friends.
author: Michelle L.

description:
Its been a while since my tummy has been so distended from such a good meal! Make sure you come to Tuba famished because the portions are quite sizable. 

I shared a delicious hot crab cake appetizer with a nice glass of white wine. Moist, nutty and flavorful. Both the chicken shish kebab and sirloin/lamb kebab dishes were tender and well seasoned.  They were accompanied by hefty portions of tasty rice and perfectly cooked veggies. Yum!

The atmosphere is very cozy and casual. The service was stellar. They were very friendly and attentive. Definitely the first choice for me the next time I have Turkish food cravings. Next time I'll save some room for their dessert and coffee.
author: Rodel B.

description: Kunefe was delicious, ordered the Hunkar begendi the first time I was there and even though I really wanted to try something new the second time there, I had to have it again!
author: Abby B.

description: The food is fantastic. The server was nice. My girlfriend is Turkish and she said it's the best Turkish food in the city. Of course she says that her mom makes some of the dishes better, but who wouldn't say that? We have gone three times and I always leave full and happy. Fantastic food. Everything is delicious.
author: David S.

description: Really good food and very friendly service. The portions are quite large but so delicious we finished it all!!
author: aude h.

description: Who knew that a "Restaurant and Grill" called Tuba was actually a Turkish eatery?  Could have fooled me... anyways, the food is delicious and the service is great.  Maybe the waiter will even perform some tricks for you if you order tea...
author: Danny C.

description: I agree with others that this is a good date place.  I don't think you could possibly go wrong here... Ever!  We had the falafel salad and a zuchini appetizer.  We both liked the salad the most, shared both items and were completely stuffed (generous portions!)  Our waitress was very friendly.  We can't wait to come back.
author: David H.

description:
Over the past few years, I became addicted to Redwood City's New Kapadokia, one of the previous ventures of the fellows who started Tuba.  Living in the City, I wasn't going to complain about Turkish food being now a thirty minute WALK from my house rather than a thirty minute DRIVE -- so I decided to bring a date and check it out.  And in many ways, these guys have upped their game.

The decor is nice; it creates a good ambience.  We brought our own bottle of wine (Tuba doesn't yet have their liquor license), but there's no corkage fee -- and the place was full last night, so I'm sure the liquor store a few doors down is running a tidy profit.  We ordered what ended up being far too much food, but we wanted to try as much as possible.  

For appetizers, we got the Ezme (red pepper paste, which is the same as New Kapadokia's, and one of the sources of my addiction to that place) and the Feta Prawns, which were excellent; the sauce they came with made for great bread dipping.  We got two entrees and a salad.  The Beyti (meat wrapped in lavash bread) was quite good, and the lamb chops expertly grilled.  The salad was merely decent; I think it came with breaded prawns.  Dessert was something that had pine nuts in it, and it came topped with ice cream; I'm still trying to figure out how we managed room in our stomachs to eat it.  

The staff was quite attentive and made sure we had plenty of bread and water.  We came in late, so the head manager chatted with us for a while at the end of the evening.  All in all, an easy decision of five stars, and I'll most certainly be back!
author: Shawn A.

description:
I don't know what I was expected when I initially saw the sign for the restaurant (before it actually opened). Maybe some sort of American food. But imagine my surprise when my friend and I walked in and found out it was actually Mediterranean food and that it was packed on an early Sunday evening. 

The food was quite delicious. I played it safe with the chicken kebabs, but my friend branched out and tried some spicy lamb and sirloin dish. The falafel salad was also quite nice. 

Still not sure what the place had to do with Tubas, but I'll definitely be back!
author: Rebecca H.

description:
I'm always impressed by a place that is friendly and helpful, but largely gets out of your way so you can enjoy a meal with friends.

Went here on a Friday night with a group 13 deep.  We had a reservation but not all of our people showed up on time.  They seated us anyways and were really patient with us as we got settled and waited for people to arrive.  Even when we were kind of blocking the doorway, they didn't get irate and let us take our time.  I know how unwieldy a large group like that is, so I really appreciated their patience with us.

The food was delicious!!  I don't know that I've had much other Turkish food to compare it to, but it was good.  We got the "Patlcan salatas grilled" eggplant puree appetizer on my side of the table which was really good.  Large chunks of garlic yummmm.  The bread and butter were really tasty too.  For my entree I got the beef ravioli (I don't remember what it's called, started with an M) in some sort of tomato yogurt sauce.  It was so good I ate it all, which is pretty rare for lil ol' me!  Also had the Turkish pilsner Effe, which was pretty good as well.

Once our large and unwieldy group had finished eating, we stayed on chatting (part of this large group were six high school friends, some of whom hadn't seen each other in 8 years) for a good 20 min.  Which could be kind of a jerk move if the place was busy, but there wasn't anyone waiting for a table by that point.  The wait staff never rushed us or asked us to move along, again I really appreciate that sort of thing.

To summarize: Yummy food, good atmosphere, friendly (but not overbearing) staff.  We stayed here for at least 2.5 hours and enjoyed every minute of it!
author: Christie C.

description: Quality Turkish Food. Appetizers are very good. I went for the Beyti as the main and was not disappointed. I was also pleasantly surprised by the rice pudding (sutlac) which is a hard one get right and it was delicious.Definitely coming back.
author: Ural Y.

description:
Wonderful Turkish food with a great wait staff. 

This place is good for a relaxed date or meal with friends. 

Ok.. do you like lamb? yes?  You will LOVE their lamb.  no? why?  you don't like gamey meat?  You will LOVE their lamb.  Oh my god!  Thank you. Finally.  A place that knows how to prepare and cook lamb.  There is not one hint of gaminess.  It is simply delicious.  The lamb chops are marinated for 3 days and oh so delish.  I had the lamb shank special, and it was literally falling off the bone - fork tender and delicious.  So so so delicious.  Did I say try the lamb?  Really.. if you read any of my reviews, because I know how lamb is "supposed"to taste (like it does here) I have a hard time eating it in places that don't know how to prepare it. 

The falafel with the goat cheese center... YUM!  oh so good. 

My brother really liked the Cevizli Ezme (walnut red pepper paste)

I also highly recommend the crabcake, falafel, and borek (boregi). The lentil soup is wonderful, fresh & hit the spot. I wouldn't say it is the 'best" but I will definitely order it again.  

The feta prawns I thought were ok- my mom loved them. 

The icli kofte (kibbeh) was not crispy on the outside as it should be, but had good flavor.  I would order it again hoping that it was an off batch. 

The Mucver (zucchini fritters) also had great flavor but was too wet in the center both times I ordered them.  It may be a consistency you like, but I prefer it them a bit more dry & with a little bit of crispiness on the outside.  

For dessert we got the baklava, Pyramid Noisette Chocolate, and Kunefe. My favorite was the pyramid. The kunefe was so good. The baklava was a bit dry & I was told that it depends on the batch of baklava, since it is made in house.  This may be a factor.. ask if  the baklava is moist or dry that day :-) 

I can't wait to go back!
author: N A.

description: This place was really good! I definitely recommend the mixed grill platter to share with 1 or 2 others. So much deliciousness. We also got the lentil soup and the hot appetizer platter- both great. Will definitely be back!
author: Dana S.

description:
2.5 stars really
I love Turkish food, but sadly Tuba doesn't have it, not compared to Troya or A la Turca... it's just ok. Service is great.
author: S. R.

description:
Friends of mine took me to Tuba on Sunday.  It is cozy inside, with an intimate feel.  Like another reviewer, we were greeted right away with a smile and quickly seated. Service was excellent.  The manager waited on us at first and suggested the Turkish beer.  Very tasty!  We started with the Tuba cold platter.  Delicious!  I recognized the humus and the rolled grape leaves, but not much else.  Didn't matter - very yummy.  Our meals were great as well.  I played is safe and ordered the lamb kabob.  Done perfectly to my medium (pink!) order.  The lamb had great flavor!  And the vegetables were very nicely grilled (not barely seared and raw like so many places).  And the rice had wonderful flavor as well.  My friends order the special that night - lamb shank is too was excellent.  I went for it and had dessert.  The rice pudding is GREAT!

Final comment - the service was super; attentive without being intrusive and the meal was timed beautifully.
author: Ellen B.

description:
Tuba is a wonderful authentic Turkish spot. The mezes brought me back to the wonderful flavors of Istanbul, with a few using appropriate California twists. For example, a salad including falafel filled with goat cheese and a little chopped avocado in the mix. Nothing wrong with bringing local ingredients to liven up an already great green salad. 

I went opening night and was impressed by the quality of service...I was happy to leave a little room for "kinks", but it wasn't necessary. One of the owners checked in with us several times--his warmth and sense of humor gives this place a family-feel. 

I had the adana kebab and asked for a little extra spice; it was cooked perfectly, full of flavor and not dry at all. My friends had the mixed grill and I tried a bit of the lamb chop which melted in my mouth.  I look forward to going back and trying some other goodies I miss from my days of living in Turkey.
author: Clara I.

description:
I was really happy with Tuba and don't just think it was "A-OK" but "A-OK!" (said with enthusiasm).  I was sad that there wasn't a large man playing a tuba when we entered as I had imagined, but the food was good and very Turkish-esk.

I enjoyed my glass of wine and the goat-cheese-stuffed-falafel salad.  I would highly recommend this salad.

I ordered the shrimp scampi but was served the shrimp kabobs.  No problem!  The main difference is the sauce and they were marvelous about bringing me the sauce on the side.  Chris L. got a ground lamb dish which he said looked, tasted and acted exactly like many a dish he enjoyed while in Turkey last September.  So, I guess this place is authentic!
author: Heather E.

description:
We just tried this new neighborhood Turkish joint and loved it. The food is great and the staff is absolutely charming. 

The salads are exceptional--fav' was the pistachio-crusted prawn salad. The kebabs were very good--crowd pleaser was the kofte. The best dish we had was the beyti. Try it. Oh so good. 

I'm so stoked to have this little gem join the neighborhood.
author: David C.

description:
My first experience with Turkish food and I'm smitten.

I went here last week with my new Turkish friend who took it upon himself to introduce me to this amazing cuisine. We started out with Dolmas, which I have had before and enjoy, and Icli Kofte which were DELICIOUS! I've been thinking about them ever since and can't wait to have them again. Basically they're made of spicy ground lamb breaded and fried into the shape of a small football. My mouth is watering.

From there we moved to the main courses: Hunkar Begendi and Beyti Adana. The first one is unlike anything else we have in America. It's basically mashed potatoes made out of eggplant. I was perplexed. And of course, it's topped with delectable lamb chunks. The second entree was again lamb, wrapped in dough with yogurt and a tomato sauce.

Lastly, dessert. Obviously, I was getting pretty full, but if I was gonna go Turkish, I was gonna go big. So for dessert we got Kunefe. I ate it, loved it, and then asked what it was....CHEESE! Baked stringy cheese covered in honey sauce and pistachios. Amazing!
author: Victoria A.

description:
this lovely restaurant reminded me of the truly awesome food while i lived in the middle east - such good memories! 

Seriously good food!. absolutely best falafal I have ever had!!!  amazingly light & crispy with a nice 'bite' in the spices. Wpnderful Hummus & pita bread -- the Salads were Perfect and the Herbed Chicken.. OH MY!! - can you say Melt in your mouth?? 

Now, understand, i am Not a cheese person (am the cat among the mice at my house) but the Feta Cheese was so perfect even I was going back for more!! i dont know if they make their own but i would buy it to take home if i could! -

MAKE RESERVATIONS - it's very popular & busy. Staff were very nice and helpful.

my only issue was noise, but to be fair i am partially deaf so loud restaurants are hard for me to cope with anyway.

I DO recommend them highly!
my only regret is that they are so far away from home- but what a great excuse to go visit the "City"
author: R L J.

description: The food was just okay. The atmosphere and service were very good though.  They accommodated us with a baby in stroller.
author: Meredith G.

description:
I happened upon this place rather randomly and I was quite happy I did,
this place is run by the same people that run a casual turkish place in the sunset. This is his nice white table cloth venture.. 
And I must say he's done well, the prices are slightly higher then I would like but at the same time I don't feel ripped off the food is fantastic. my only slight complaint is the hummus is just hummus it could be a bit more interesting but this place is great I've already been here twice in two weeks, and I will be back
author: Sasha A.

description: We loved tuba!  Food was amazingly tasty and fresh.  Meat-stuffed dumplings were a little bland, and the prices were a little spendy - but that said, we LOVED our apps and the wrapped skewers mad stuffed eggplant and Turkish beers.  Service was wonderful.  Tuba is great, you should try it!!
author: Julia B.

description:
This was my second time to Tuba and I was even more impressed than on my first visit.  We were a large group (9 people) and the servers were very attentive and helpful.  Our main server was friendly with a nice smile, something that isn't necessary, but certainly helps make the dining experience extra enjoyable.  Stuffed falafel salad was delicious, and the hummus and dolmas were some of the best I've had in the city.  

Extra bonus points for the following:

1) We had a birthday in our group and they surprised us with a lovely chocolate dessert.    

2) The woman at the table next to our accidentally knocked her glass of wine over and it fell to the floor and broke.  Not only did the servers clean it immediately (as would be expected), but they brought the patron a full new glass of wine as well (really nice touch!).

I definitely recommend Tuba, the food and service was great, and it worked really well for a group dinner.
author: Girldancing C.

description:
In a nut shell- the food was pretty good but nothing that I will be running around to tell everyone about. A perfect place to come with a group of friends for good food, large portions, decent prices AND it is BYOB.

The waiters are great and very nice and accommodating. It was also really easy to make a reservation for 5 people on a Thursday evening - when I called that afternoon.

Parking can be rough as it is all street parking. Yikes!

Yummy, relaxed and fun atmosphere. I'd go again.
author: Liz S.

description:
Great portion sizes for a reasonable price and I really liked the Adana kofte.  It hit the right balance between spiced and meaty - I came here with a vegetarian but I love kebabs and doner type food.  Maybe the help was a bit overburdened while we ate but we were never left thirsty or hungry.

BYOB is great while it lasts and I'm glad to see this little place succeeding.
author: Michael S.

description:
A welcome addition to the Mission that I hope will continue to thrive despite it's cursed retail space.

The salad portions are enormous! My husband and I each ordered one as a starter. The Pistachio-crusted Shrimp Salad was  tossed in a spicy vinagrette, while the Falafel Salad, our favorite perhaps in part to the soft goat cheese melted in each of the 4 falafel balls.  (For a lighter dining experience I  recommend splitting salad orders with a friend).

As an entree, my husband ordered a traditional Turkish dish called Hunkar Begendi which is a smoky eggplant puree drizzled with a tomato sauce and topped with small cubes of stewed lamb.  Although the flavor of the dish was remarkable, the lack of texture made it less interesting, but was defintitely worth experiencing.  

I played it safe with their Stuffed Salmon dish, which isn't actually "stuffed' at all, but instead topped with pan fried onions (and something else?).  This dish was both attractive, cooked perfectly and tasty and I would recommend it to salmon lovers.

Tuba Restaurant is rather small so I strongly encourage making a reservation.  The staff does their best to accommodate walk-ins, but the result is too many tables which we all know equates to over-crowding and undue chaos.  I'm hoping they'll remove a few tables soon and correct this one downfall going forward in hopes to teach us each us all to plan ahead with a reservation that is worth the wait
author: Lady D S.

description:
This place is a hidden gem. Located near many bars within walking distance and a nice romantic but not too romantic setting I will surely be back.
The Içli Kofte ( spiced ground sirloin in a crispy bulgur shell) was off the hook ... so delicious I will get this again. 
The hummus was a little off for my tastes... it was REALLY creamy tasting ... almost concentrated tasting. The lamb kabobs were some of the best I have had.
They were out of like 3 different dishes and after the waitress or kitchen made the mistake of letting us order something they were out of .. they ended up comping that entree. THAT is how you run a successful business. 
The wine is not overpriced, the ambiance is nice, the food was delicious and the service although a little off was still courteous and accommodating.

This is a new place... show them some love.
author: Jeremy R.

description: Okay so here' s the deal.  i was struggling between 3 and 4 stars because i really really enjoyed the food - but i wasn't sure if the novelty of it really made it special or if it was the food itself.  The matti and moussakah were really really good - like 5 star good.  But the warm plate starter had a few bland apps which could have been twisted into something uniquely san francisco and flavorful.  the service was timely and excellent, though often we were confused by who was our real server (3 really nice people helped us.) parking is tough but knew this going into it so no star reduction for parking. 3 or 4....humph am i tough critic? oh all right i'll give it 4.  but only because damian says so.
author: Norman P.

description:
I really wanted to love this restaurant.  The location, ambience and decor are all terrific.  The portions were large however they truly lacked flavor.  (Do they not have ANY spices or even salt and pepper in that kitchen??)  I paid $2 for hot tea, which was served in a tiny shot glass -- totally impossible to pick up because it was boiling hot and there was no handle.  We ordered hummus and it came with a loaf of bread to put it on -- much too heavy.  I asked about pita bread and they brought tiny pita chips about the size of a dime.  The pistachio-encrusted shrimp in the salad was over-cooked and heavy.  

The servers and host  were incredibly nice and very friendly and helpful but all-in-all...Sorry-- it was a huge disappointment and because there are so many other places to try, I doubt that I will give Tuba another chance...
author: Bette S.

description:
We live nearby & have been meaning to try it for a while; we finally ended up going because of a Groupon, and weren't disappointed!

After considering several different tasty-sounding dishes, we settled on the Stuffed Falafel Salad, a huge plate of tasty greens in light Mediterranean dressing with tangy avocado salsa, with three giant falafels filled with melted goat cheese.  For entrees, I had the sauteed chicken, which is like a hearty Mediterranean chicken stew, served in a piping hot bowl with mushrooms, olives, and cheese in a super flavorful tomato/herb broth.  Served with rice and salad on the side; try dumping the rice into the stew for a risotto effect.  My boyfriend had the, Hünkar Beendi, pureed eggplant with mozzarella cheese topped with lamb cubes.  Also very tasty!

A word of caution - they tend to be very busy, especially on the weekend, so it doesn't hurt to make a reservation.  We went around 7:30 on a Friday evening without & waited 40 minutes.  Service was a little bit slow, but not egregiously so.

We'll be back!
author: Angela B.

description: Great service and food. We has the hummus, stuffed eggplant and Beyti Adana which were all really good.
author: Vish N.

description: The food here is pretty good. Tried the mixed grill but couldn't finish everything. This is because you get so much food! Great service too.
author: Jason A.

description:
I'm a fan of Tuba. I was here with a friend on Tuesday night, and they were surprisingly busy for a weeknight. Nonetheless, the service was attentive and friendly.

We ordered several items from the menu, and all were very good. The kunefe dessert is distressingly addictive. (Having learned today that the chef worked at New Kapadokia in Redwood City, which is a favorite of mine, I'm not surprised by the yuminess.) In addition, prices are very reasonable, especially for the neighborhood. My only regret is the lack of elma çay on the  menu. Even still, I'll be back early and often!

As of this week they still don't have a liquor license, so corkage is free. I'm not in a hurry for that to change, but I assume it will eventually.
author: senga d.

description:
This place is a great new (to me, at least) Mission spot.

I searched Yelp for a place I had not yet been in the Mission for a reunion with friends I had gone way-too-long without a dinner with and found Tuba.  The menu looked great so we gave it a try.

We appreciated the varied wine menu and ordered a $20 bottle of wine along with the Cold Appetizer plate, the zucchini cakes, crab cakes and falafel and goat cheese salad - so much food for three of us and so tasty.  The cold dips were a great selection, the bread is similar to what I have had at other Mediterranean places (tho I do prefer pita) and was bountiful, the crab cakes were VERY yummy, and the falafel, both bites with the goat cheese and without, were exceptional. The only complaint was how oily the food was, but damn, it tasted great, and it was nice not to be rushed as we dipped and ate through out treats.

I'd highly recommend this place for a tapas-like dinner, though I also want to go back to try some of their tasty sounding dinner plates.

Well priced, great service, and nice variation.  Can't wait to return.
author: Sarah X.

description: What a treat! I wasn't familiar with Turkish food at all before going, I had very nice lamb kabobs and the humus appetizer. Really liked the small vegetables sides that were accompanied with the rice on the kabob plate . Had nice red wine and to top it off the Turkish dessert called Künefe suggested by the oh so friendly owners. This dessert was so unique - shredded dough, cheese and syrup = yummy! I will definitely come back with more friends.
author: Tere C.

description: at random we walked into Tuba in hopes of an at least mediocre meal after having found out our initial destination was closed. to our welcomed surprise Tuba delivered on giving is an awesome, extra delicious dinner. the complimentary bread had great spreads to accompany it. the manti (little dumplings with garlic yogurt sauce and mint) were my favorite thing we ordered. the dumplings were really small and almost more like tiny ravioli and were oh so yummy! the kofte kebab was tasty and the kunefe was awesome! the service was good and the people seemed to genuinely care whether you enjoyed your dinner or not. I will absolutely be back!
author: Regina C.

description:
We thought Tuba was terrific. Good, freshly-made food. Friendly wait staff. The waiter, who turned out to be the son of the woman who owns the restaurant, wrote down the names of a couple of things we liked (cacik and haydori) so we could look them up on the Internet and try making them ourselves. We definitely will return and bring more friends. 
Sally
author: Sally O.

description:
PROS:  Flavorful food with an authentic Turkish atmosphere.
CONS: Rather small space, call ahead for reservations.

Four of us went to dinner at Tuba. We called around 6:00 for a reservation and were able to book that evening at 8:15pm. The restaurant is still relatively new as of this post (opened in December 2009), so this could change as the restaurant matures.


AMBIENCE
A warm and cozy Mediterranean feel. Dark rich colors (deep reds, browns, etc.), give it a warm feeling while the various vases and art throughout made it feel authentic. There are about 6-8 four-tops running along each side of the restaurant which can be pushed together for larger parties. And there were about 3-5 two tops that ran along the center. Point being, it's relatively small. 

SERVICE
The night we were there, they only had 2 waiters, however, we never felt like we were waiting for too long to receive attention. We asked for one special request which was promptly served. Our water and wine glasses were refilled and our plates were removed quickly upon finishing. 

FOOD
The food was very tasty. We ordered the hummus, which oddly didn't come with pita or flat bread of any kind. (This was our special request). We shared a few dishes including the hot appetizer sampler, Greek salad, ground sirloin and chicken kabobs. Portions were hearty and all tasted good.

PRICE
There are a lot of options depending how much you want to spend. Appetizers and salads can run between $6 - $15. Entrees are the more 'normal' price of $12-$20.
