Note at the time of this review they don't have their liquor license so they are allowing you to bring in your own bottles of wine (there's a liquor store around the corner) without a corkage fee. [read: go today for a good deal on dinner ! ]  :)
author: carrie w.

description: Good stuff. Especially enjoyed the peynirli karides (prawn appetizer dish) and the sarma beyti kebab, which is a must-have amazing dish!!!
author: shannon a.

description:
I can't speak for everyone else's experience with their service, but we thought everyone was very nice and helpful - we thought it was pretty entertaining when another table's waiter commented on how "yummy" our food looked.  Plus, Tuba is the only restaurant that allows you to bargain for reservations.  A snippet of our phone conversation:

Me: Do you have a table for two available tonight at 7:00?
Tuba: I'm sorry sir, we are really busy tonight - does 6:30 work?
Me: No, that'll be too early, I'm coming straight from work...
Tuba: How about 8:00?  We have a great table for two at that time...
Me: Hmmm...well, I am pretty hungry...how about 7:00?
Tuba: Sure, I see an opening - see you at 7:00!

Service aside, this is the best Mediterranean I've had in SF (sorry La Mediterranee - but you've had that spot on my list for 3 years now).  Dinner started out on a low point - we had the dolmas, which were pretty blah.  Between our shrimp kebabs and salmon, both our main courses were excellent - the salmon had an explosion of flavors I don't usually associate with salmon or med food.  Finally, kunefe for dessert was absolutely amazing - it's proves that if baklava ever met sweet cheese and then had an affair with pistachos, they'd have delicious kids.  Wait scratch that metaphor, it sounds creepy and doesn't make sense...you would actually end up with two sort of tasty desserts instead of single really delicious one.    

Anyways, the only downsides of this place are that it's a bit cramped/small and parking sucks - but they're both small prices to pay for some tasty Turkish food.  I'll definitely be back soon!
author: Rosers M.

description: The food is yummy, the place is small and cute. That said, they are not prepared to do Ramadan meals.
author: Sara S.

description:
Mediterranean food is my comfort food.

The falafel salad is delicious. Crispy on the outside with gooey, melty goat cheese on the inside. I love my salads with lemony dressing--this one was just to my liking. I eat babies. Well, baby sheep, at least. And the folks at Tuba cooked those babies well.  Try the lamb kebab. It comes with julienned veggies, cucumber-yogurt dipping sauce, and aromatic rice. I left feeling full and happy. No complaints on the service either. They were all pleasant and speedy with the food.
author: Alyssa T.

description:
This place was recommended to me by a coworker - I would never have found it otherwise, but I'm glad to have it in my neighborhood rotation now. 

I shared the mixed cold and hot appetizer plates ($20 each). This place isn't cheap, but the quality of the ingredients explains why. Everything was fresh and tasty. These appetizer dishes were also enough to make a meal for two of us. I plan to go back and try the entrees next time. Our server was incredibly sweet as well. Nice neighborhood spot.
author: Julia G.

description:
I've traveled to Turkey five times the past five years, including a stint of five months the last time there.  My number one love and activity there has been the food.  

I really wanted to love this place, but it is unfair for me to expect what you would experience food-wise in Turkey here in San Francisco, but I can't help to compare.  All things considered, I thought the food at Tuba was good, the service very good.

I was so excited to try this place and never would have known about it had I not seen their Groupon offer (thank you for offering up one as adding incentive to try and making your presence know in SF).  The name doesn't exactly imply Turkish, so never would have known.  I've walked by this place a few times in the past and had no idea.  I'm always on the lookout for Turkish restaurants, especially with menus that go beyond kebap and baklava.  Tuba certainly does.

The front of house staff were super friendly and accommodating.  We didn't have a reservation and the place was packed, but they were able to seat us anyway.  We had a few appetizers, entree, and desert.

Food-wise, the highlight was the Kunefe with a little tea (in the little curvy Turkish tea glasses at that) to wash it down.  I never had Kunefe like this in Turkey.  The Tuba version had generous amount of cheese filling really made it stand out.

Overall, yes this place is worth a try, the food is good, service friendly, ambiance ok, but if you have experienced Turkish food in Turkey and are expecting the same, you may be a little disappointed.
author: eugene c.

description: Now this restaurant is complete garbage!!! Literally.  Since management change as of last year, food quality is not up to par with other restaurants.  New chef is pretty bad, avoid it if you can.  They try to save money every way, smaller plate size, higher prices, even lower their lights, so you can hardly see anything.  Avoid.
author: Alex R.

description: Awesome food. Great wait staff. Will go there again, and again. Vegetarians will be happy too. Love Tuba!
author: K H.

description:
I can't speak more highly of Tuba. I went last night for my birthday and the owner greeted me himself. My table of 10 was plied with goodies and attention for the remainder of the evening. I had never met the owner before but everyone at my table hugged him as we left. Yep, it's that kind of place. And he's that kind of guy. 

Both sampler platters are incredible (cold and hot), as are all shish kebabs, and both salads (goat cheese stuffed falaffel? Yes please). The Turkish pilsner is crisp and delicious and they actually have some really decent wines on the list. 

All in all, a really great mid-price restaurant.
author: Meredith S.

description:
Went there twice and would highly recommend them.

The first time we tried Musakka and Hunkar Begendi, both of which were very successfully executed. Their Kunefe was GREAT (unlike others I have tried in the Bay Area).

On a second occasion we shared a hot and a cold platter of appetizers, then tried Beyti and Manti. Beyti was great, but I didn't find their Manti to be so successful.

Plusses for serving Efes Pilsner :)
author: Cemre G.

description: Tuba's unattractive signage belies its sultry interior, a prime date spot tucked away on a less-busy stretch of the Mission.  The Mixed Grill is an achievement, with both ground and whole meats served at the right level of doneness.  App lovers should note that Tuba no longer honors LevelUp transactions, which I discovered too late, rendering my $10.00 credit useless.
author: Vin J.

description:
We enjoyed our dining experience here last Saturday before taking in the Marga Gomez show down around the corner.   I'll get the cons out of the way first and explain why I took off a star:  My girlfriend remarked that our waitness looked like she could have used a good meal herself, and that she seemed rather listless and unattentive.  I had to ask her twice for lemon for my drink, the yummy bread was removed from our table to make room for our salads without asking us if we would like to keep it.  Finally, when my girl friend paid with a credit card, she noted that it was left unattended for quite a while at the station where anyone could have picked it up.  She did tell a man who said he was the owner and he was quite apologetic for this having happened.  

Now the pros:  Delicious Turkish food of which we had, between us, a mixed grill shishkabob, a prawn salad with pistascios and mango salsa (could have used more of this!), another salad with chopped tomatos and cucumbers, a grilled steak, both of the entrees came with very flavorful rice, and we both split a creme brule'and a hazelnut noisette pyramid for dessert.  Five stars for the food, but a scarce three stars for service.
author: ruth r.

description:
Adds flavor and vibrancy to a sometimes iffy (food-wise) block... I've noticed restaurants come and go on this block, and I hope Tuba stays. Friendly and attentive wait staff, and the food is AMAZING. I love Turkish food, and Tuba hits the spot. Loved their Combination appetizer (hummus, tzatiki- like dish, dolmas, and more) and also tried their chicken and lamb skewers. It was all fantastic and reasonably priced. 

Not to mention, Tuba is a cute name...
Five toots for tuba!
(insert flatulence joke here)
author: Fonz Z.

description:
Best.  Lambchops.  EVER!

Friendly service, delicious food, relaxing ambiance.    A little pricey, but it's also a step up in flavor and quality from over-the-counter middle eastern food.

Come eat at Tuba.  If you see a guy in a grey fedora at the back with a big pile  of lamb bones on his plate, that's me.
author: Vince D.

description: Really nice ambience and great service. The food is authentic and delicious. Definitely recommend trying this place out.
author: murat k.

description:
Although I'm a vegetarian, I was still able to eat something--and it was all yummy. Our waitress was super nice and super friendly. 

I do think the name is slightly strange and misleading. Apparently it is a Turkish name but when it is preceding "Restaurant and Grill," I tend to think of something other than Turkish cuisine (still trying to sort that one out). 

But otherwise, lovely place. Good ambiance.
author: Caitanya M.

description:
So excited to have a new addition to the neighborhood!

Great food, cooked up with lots of love.  Wonderful friendly service and reasonable prices. Who could ask for more?

Looking forward to going again.
author: Abigail M.

description:
Really good food- except for the crab cakes, which were pretty average- and very friendly service, a short walk away.
Bonus points for fresh warm bread and herbed butter.
Actually, every single business in America should have that standard.
Mmm. Butter.
author: Jonny A.

description:
We checked out Tuba on opening night, expecting their to be opening night kinks... but no.  We loved everything about it.  The food was amazing, the service was perfect.  The waiter know what he was talking about even the doors had opened for the first time just two hours earlier.  Prices are completely reasonable.

I recommend the mixed grill... lamb, chicken and other tasty turkish meat preparations.  All were perfectly cooked.  The head guy was friendly gracious, visiting our table numerous times, and bringing a treat that we didn't order.  The apps were so good, so flavorful, that even though I was full I couldn't stop eating.  We were with a friend who has lived in Turkey and she marveled at how authentic everything was.

Another great dish is the grilled chicken with a savory sauce of tomato, garlic, pepper, onion, etc.  It was perfect, as were the lamb chops, which are so easy to over or under cook but these were just right.

The bread, herbed butter, and tomato garlic spread were so good that you have to be careful to save room 'cause you're not going to want to leave anything on your plate.

The atmosphere is elegant but you can definitely come as you are, it's  not stuffy at all.  You just want to sit down and eat.  It's a very cozy place, the kind of spot that's equally good for dates, family gatherings, friends getting together, etc.

On a block that has had numerous restaurants of varying degrees of success, it's great to have something this good that doesn't break the bank.

Highly recommended.
author: Aaron W.

description: This place is fantastic. I'm gluten-free and dairy-free and sensitive to a thousand other foods, and the staff at Tuba accommodated all my questions and served me one of the best meals I've had in the neighborhood!
author: Laura T.

description:
I had the chance to try out Tuba because my friend purchased me a Coupon over one of those community coupon like buy w/ me sites.. kind of like a Groupon Site... so, my date and I decided to go there after a long day of shopping. We were greeted very poorly at the door by the hostess. She treated us like we were vagrants since we had the coupon, and she knew nothing about it. She then calls a manager, didn't even offer to seat us, and the manager acted confused. So I tried to explain to them that I have this coupon, and they may check with their sources. So She goes and calls the boss, and then comes back much nicer, and seats us. What that shows to me is that they have poor communication in their restaurant management. I think it all started off with the wrong vibe and the way they treated us. I don't know if it's because my date was African American or maybe simply because they weren't familiar with the coupon deal, but they were not very nice to us at all, and at no point did I feel welcome.

We sit down, and proceed to order food. The cold appetizer platter was well presented and delicious, bread was very good.

The Entres were huge, simply too much food for one person to eat. We got the Eggplant puree with lamb cubes, which was mediocre at best. My salad dish had giant Falafels but they didn't taste very fresh or flavorful. I couldn't finish any of it, so we packed it up for the dog.


Decor was nice, food was generally well presented, though flavors were very mediocre since I've had phenomenal MiddleEastern food.. If you go to Shalizar or even Alibaba however the hostess' unfriendly demeanor really ruined our experience. I will not return.
author: Mars D.

description:
Get the Falafel salad!!  It's a wonderful combination.  

The portions are huge, the place is small.  It's a winning combination.  It's a good place for a date if you like to share.  

Parking is always a pain.

As of this review it's free corkage!  

www.sfcorkagefees.com
author: Brittney B.

description: I decided to go this place after reading the reviews on Yelp. I tried chicken sauté and really liked it. The taste of the food is very closed to the ones in Turkey. They have a very attractive plate presentation.
author: Afsin O.

description: Fantastic Turkish food!! Great service and ambience
author: Raghavan V.

description: Great portions, great taste, wonderful atmosphere and friendly staff.  The only gripe is the parking but that is to be expected for mission district so no fault to Tuba on that one.  Also watch for the "Evil Eye"
author: Levi B.

description: Great place for some really great food at a reasonable price.  Decent priced wine list to top it off. Falafel salad is excellent and can easily be a meal.  Enjoy.
author: Annette M.

description: *Love this place* - the food is really authentic and the service is awesome. I always make reservations before going and have never had to wait to be seated. The food is seriously delicious and I appreciate the recommendations they provide. Anything with eggplant is to die for, and their bread with their pepper humus is excellent. I would recommend Tuba to anyone! Also, try out the Turkish beer - love it.
author: Ana M.

description: Great restaurant. Authentic Turkish cuisine. the Manti is dellicious. Adana kebap is very tender and tasty.
author: Bulent E.

description:
This was place was Ok.  Met a friend for an early dinner.  The menu is pretty standard - there were a few surprises. For example, an avocado salsa on one of the salads and the pistachio encrusted prawns.  Being it was our first time at the restaurant, we decided to go basic with the cold appetizer platter, the sauteed shrimp in the pepperoncini sauce, and a side of the falafel. We also ordered a couple of glasses of wine.  

I'd give more stars for the ambiance, decor, and all over set-up.  Tuba does have a nice, cozy vibe.  Even romantic.  The artwork is an interesting choice - my friend had just had her eyes dilated and wondered if the paintings she saw were the result of her slightly blurred version. 

To start they offer complimentary bread accompanied by a nondescript red aioli type item, a few chunks of feta, and one olive.  The bread was my favorite part of the meal.  The server  indicated that they make it fresh daily.  The feta was nice and my friend and I split the one olive. The dip was flavorless.

We waited quite awhile for our wine - it was early - three servers - not a lot of tables. We caught our server's attention and inquired about the wine --- it ended-up arriving with the meal. Everything came at the same - the hot and cold dishes - which is one of my peeves.  Plus, there wasn't ample space for all of the dishes.  I understand that we ordered all small plates, but they could've asked about the delivery pattern.  

Service, despite the wait, was still friendly and personable.  

Now for the food. The platter consisted of dolmas,  hummus, ezme, an eggplant salad, spinach dip, a thick yogurt, a caviar dip, and a white bean salad.  The portions were typical.  The food was 50/50. Overall,  I've had better in other Turkish restaurants and homemade by Turkish friends.  The best items were the hummus, the eggplant salad, the thick yogurt, and spinach dip. 

The falafel were nothing special and for me, the shrimp were overcooked.  The sauce was Ok - I wanted more zip.  

The food pricing was fine.  The wine was also reasonably priced.  

i wouldn't go back - I didn't get enough flavor nor that mom and pop feel on the plate that I so appreciate in these types of restaurants.
author: Carson R.

description:
Food:
It could have been the non meat dishes we ordered but the food was just average.  Some below average in flavor.  We had the Tuba hot appetizers platter and a salad.   I'm confused as the rest of the yelpers out there seem to love this place.   My recommendation is if you go order a proper entree or meat dish.

Service:
Minus the fact that they appeared to have lost our reservation (we waited 25 minutes for our table), the waitress serving us was friendly and helpful. It would have been nice if the manager would have offered us a glass a wine while we waited for our table instead of just pointing to the bar and telling us to wait there (no service at the bar until we asked too...)
author: Aus B.

description: My first time at Tuba and my friend and I loved it.  We are planning to come back with our men soon.
author: Kristina V.

description: Really good food, charming staff, but one glaring flaw: the pleasant young gal who bussed the table spent several minutes stacking every dish in one big pile before precariously removing the whole pile - tacky, dangerous, and made us literally have to stop our conversation while she blocked us to build a tower of dirty dishes. I hope Tuba owner is reading Yelp and teaches his staff how to clear a table more professionally.
author: tw s.

description: A hidden gem in the neighborhood. I don't know why I didn't go here long before. They have lovely dishes and big portions.
author: Heather D.

description:
I Gotta give it 5 stars. I'm trying to think of something to complain about but I got nothing.  Everything I ordered was good, nice decor, big portions, and a good price.  
We ordered the mixed grill plate, 2 soups, humous plate and a salad. Couldn't come close to finishing  so we had plenty of leftovers.
author: Craig G.

description: Absolutely delicious!!! The ambiance was very relaxing and casual, yet still very cute. You must try the Turkish wine (amazing) and the fried zucchini appetizer. Service was great and food was well-prepared, tasty, and VERY reasonably priced. I went with a few friends and we split appetizers, a meal and a bottle of wine and the bill was about $15/each.
author: Nadia G.

description:
As a huge fan of Park Gyro, we heard that Tuba was opening and wanted to try it for ourselves.  What a delight. A warm homemade bread with flavored butter was set before us right away.  We decided to order dishes that we had not tried before since we were used to eating the wonderful kebabs at Park Gyro. I ran into my Turkish friends who suggested we order the "Tuba Cold Appetizer Plate" which was a great sampler of all the appetizers.  

The Patlcan salatas grilled eggplant puree, bell pepper tomato garlic on the appetizer sampler was just delicious. The Hummus pureed garbanzo beans, lemon tahini sauce was good,( but better at Park Gyro in my opinion). The Mercimek Kofte lentils, parsley, green onions, bulgur was quite tasty. Kabak Ezme zucchini, dill, mint, yogurt light garlic was light and also yummy. Piyaz white bean salad with green onions, tomato and tahini vinegar lemon sauce was very nice, but the Ezme crushed walnuts, pepper paste, tomato paste, garlic, cumin was too spicy for my palate. I really, really enjoyed the Haydari fresh dill, mint, thick yogurt, light garlic and wish I could make it myself!

For our entree, we shared Hünkar Beendi pureed eggplant with mozzarella cheese topped with lamb cubes. The eggplant had such a great smoky & creaminess that was so smooth and together with the tasty lamb cubes, it was really delicious. A very nice surprise.

For dessert, Ali (owner and chef) especially made a Künefe Two layers of kadayf (shredded fillo dough) filled with sweet cheese, baked to
perfection and served with homemade syrup and pistachio nut that was just out of this world!!!  Finished the entire plate. It was great to see Ali go around to each table to ask his patrons how their dinner was that evening. It left a very good feeling. 

The decor was very nice in warm tones of red and touches of Turkish decor. Noise level was a little loud. Service was excellent. Everyone was so friendly.  I want to go back with more friends to try more dishes!
author: Flo H.

description:
I'm a little surprised by the glowing reviews on here about Tuba.  Maybe we just had bad luck, but our experience wasn't all that great. First of all, I give them one star for finally occupying the deserted storefront that has been empty for the last few years, after the last Italian restaurant shut their doors. They also did a good job making it look nice - think red walls and dark, rich wood, which earns them another star. The appetizer platter we ordered (and falafel) were also super yummy, so thumbs up for all of that.  

The rest, however, was somewhat disappointing.  First of all, while not in a hurry, our main courses took far too long to arrive - conspicuously so.  And, when they did arrive, my veggie kabobs were cold (as if they had been sitting out for at least a half hour).  My friends' dishes were similarly disappointing. The stuffed eggplant was only so-so, and they were out of the vegetarian moussaka that we tried to order. I would maybe give them another chance after they've had a chance to work out some of the kinks.
author: SL N.

description: Great food. Some of the best Dolsa I've ever had. Warm ambiance, attentive and friendly wait staff. Lots of vegetarian options as we'll as delicious lamb. Highly recommend this place.
author: Jake L.

description: Got an early reservation and scored a window table with lots of cushions. Vegetarian friend and I had way too much to eat for two on the appetizer sampler. The spinach and yogurt salads were standouts. Large portions. Lentil soup was tasty and the pistachio crusted shrimp (four) with salad and mango salsa was great, too. Friend had falafel salad and took most of it home. Looking forward to returning to try other menu items. It was almost half-filled when we left. Lovely decor with good silverware and cloth napkins. Good service from the waiter and hostess, too.
author: Jonathan G.

description: good stuff, seems authentic, but I have no idea.  cozy place to eat, VERY generous portions!
author: christopher h.

description: Mmmmmm M. I think I'd have to call this one a hidden treasure! Beautiful turkish food, great ambiance, great staff!!! The chef eve checked on us. Get in there foodies.
author: Juliann B.

description: A refreshing alternative to asian, latin and indian fare when your taste-buds are screaming for deelish meats and some exotic flavors and spices and your senses want a cozy (thanks to the warm paint color and the dark furniture) date/friend spot that is well decorated with cool wall art.  Portions are large and service was great.  It may not be the koftes you would get in Istanbul but it is a great break from burritos, pad thai and curry.
author: Amireh G.

description: Amazing food and great service. They were very attentive and helpful in making suggestions. The lamb chops were prepared perfectly and the Tuba cold plate was flavorful and huge!
author: J Todd S.

description: This is a terriffic restaurant. (I have yet to give any business a perfect score of five stars.) the menu is varied, interesting diverse and still offers plenty of options so that the less adventurous diners in your party can still find plenty of "meat and potatos" style of options.  Perhaps my new favorite restaurant.
author: Don m.

description: We had a large group. The service was great. The ambiance was also very nice. Will definitely go back soon.
author: Lidia Z.

description:
A couple friends brought me here for a low-key birthday dinner and the whole dining experience was wonderful. The space is cozy and warm, the service is extraordinary and the food is fantastic. We had dolmas and greek salad to start the meal, both were delicious. The main dishes that followed (kebabs, salmon, etc) were all generous, beautifully presented and perfectly prepared. The capper of the night was the rice pudding with a single birthday candle, presented to me "on the house." 

FYI: While they're waiting for their liquor license, they kindly offer free corkage, so remember to bring a bottle if you're going soon.
author: Tosco R.

description: A friend gave us her groupon (thanks Carla!) so we had little expectations other than a deal on a dinner. We got adana kebab (ground serloin and lamb) and the lamb chops. Adana was juicy and spicy, lamb chops sooo tender. Both came with yummy rice and veggies which so often can be gratuitous filler but here were pretty damn good, plus the awesome herby yogurt business. Place is small and you are close to other diners, but didn't bother me (there was a lot of ooh'ing and aah'ing over neighbors' plates, as well as a random compliment on my earrings from the next table- besides the point), service was fast and non-buggy. Headed back soon for that hot fried appetizer sampler thing...
author: Abby S.

description: If I could give this restaurant more than five stars, I would. It had a great ambience, and the food was out-of-this-world good. We went here with a group of friends to celebrate my husband's birthday, and dinner was one of the highlights of the night. The staff was unbelievably helpful and accommodating - just a fantastic restaurant.
author: Kelley P.

description: Solidly great food. Very attentive and helpful staff. Didn't have to wait long for anything and all the dishes were great.
author: Noah P.

description: I love Turkish food and am glad for a white-table-cloth place in the Mission, not too far from home.  The food was fresh and tasty (had the meze and lamb kebab), and although we didn't get past the champagne on the wine list, the wine list was good and reasonably-priced.
author: Laurel B.

description: Great food, very friendly owner and staff.  We were pleasantly surprised when we chose to celebrate my birthday dinner here after poor service at another restaurant in Noe Valley.  Tuba was a delicious find, and we will go again.  Kid-friendly, good for groups.
author: Naomi M.

description: The place was nice and the food good,my 1 star less is for the tight space the place has .
author: abe s.

description:
First visit: 
Extremely slow service. Everything else was fine.

Second visit: 
Unacceptably slow service. There were plenty of waitresses per # of tables but we had to keep asking for things. Even our wine. Beverages are usually the fastest thing to come out!

I ordered the beef wrapped kofte. I started eating it and my BF dug in to it as well. When I was 1/3 into it, I started pulling out raw meat. Not RARE meat, people. RAW BEEF. We tried to get the staff's attention. We were dismissed several times and had to sit there for a long time. The waitress that finally did come over laughed about the meat. Sorry. I don't find potentially making us sick funny at all.

THEN, the thing that botheres me the most: They tried to tell me they were charging me correctly.....   
  $72 was our total 
- $18 for the uncooked beef 
- $12 for baklava we said "forget it" when it never came out
- $25 Groupon
Simple math. Comes to: $17. Our bill? $38. I just wanted out of there so I paid it to follow after my very angry BF who is Turkish and was embarassed by some of "his people" in this place. It wasnt until later thta I realized the stupid waitress screwed me over. The reason is because they totally screw over their Groupon customers. They take off a percentage NOT the $25 promised. 

PLEASE DO NOT GIVE THIS RESTAURANT YOUR MONEY. I'M NOT GOING TO TELL YOU THE NATIONALITY OF THE OWNER/MANAGER (not a fully Turkish place) OF THIS PLACE, BUT JUST BE AWARE, I KNOW FIRSTHAND THAT CERTAIN PEOPLE FROM CERTAIN PARTS OF THE WORLD ARE TAUGHT BE SHADY LIKE THIS AND YOU WILL BE CONTRIBUTING TO THIS INDECENCY IF YOU EAT HERE.

Oh, and our stomaches kept us tossing and turning all night because we did get a little ill. Thank God we did not eat more than we did!!!!!!
author: Bay Area Truth Teller Z.

description:
Food seemed to be authentic and tasted pretty good.  The service was poor.  Waited too long to be attended to once seated, and then was asked to leave once we paid the check.  Have you ever been asked to leave?   I haven't until this.  I understand the need to turn tables over, but we were only there maybe 10 minutes after paying the bill.

Too many great restaurants in the city...skip this one.
author: Roxie B.

description: I have never had Turkish Food before,But I do now. Everything was fantastic,The Kebabs were sooooooooo good. Had a great time and cannot wait to go back.
author: Jeff T.

description: Made reservations for a Friday night the day before.  Table was ready as soon as we arrived.  Great food.  The hot and cold platter appetizers were very tasty, and plenty of food for four people.  The beyti was very good.  The stuffed fish special was also really good.  Friends enjoyed their meat skewers.  The Turkish coffees hit the spot after a very filling meal, and went very well with the chocolate creme brulee.  We all had tasty leftovers to take home as well.
author: Rise G.

description: I was really impressed with the service, food, and ambiance. The server(s) were very friendly and had menu recommendations. Food was good. Ambiance was warm and thoughtful.
author: David S.

description:
OK. I told the folks I would write a nice review about them since they gave us such a great experience.  

Tuba is a nice, clean and modern Turkish restaurant, tuck between the Mission District and Noe Valley.  We would never have thought of driving to this neighborhood for dinner had it not for the Groupon deal we got (a plug for Groupon).  My Groupon would have expired to nothing, but the owner extended it for another week so I get to try their restaurant - a good business decision...

I haven't had much experience with Turkish food, but I liked what I ate there. 

The bread was warm and has tiny sesame seeds to make it smell good.  The spiced up whipped butter was perfect for spreading.  We ordered Kofte Kebab (beef and lamb) and Shrimp Scampi - both were delicious and properly done. The vegetables were nicely done and we didn't know how to eat Turkish food, so we dipped everything into everything that was on our plate.  We topped it off with their signature dessert, the Kunefe.  The Kunefe is layered shredded dough, cheese, pistachio, fried to perfection.  It was sweet, but not over sweat, but has an interesting crusty texture for a dessert.  The biggest draw for the this restaurant was the service.  The host and waitress was very kind and attentive.  They were very nice to us.  I read some recent posting that people were annoyed with the service, but I believe it might have been because of the mass number of people arriving during the final day of Groupon expiration.  It's tough running a business, but even tougher when you have impatient customers (I am one of them from time to time).

Overall 4 out of 5 Stars

-Food - tasty (good tasting food doesn't have to be authentic*)
-Menu - simple
-Cost - reasonable, not pricey at all
-Service - exceptional
-Parking - only street parking, so it's a bit difficult to do on weekends.

* I know I will get some people gasping for air when I said "good tasting food doesn't have to be authentic" so I want to clear the air.  I believe food is dynamic and can change, as long as it tastes good or better than the original.  However, I do believe authenticity is important for those who missed the taste of their homeland.  If you are tasting food for childhood memories, they have to be authentic.  My mom used to pay a lot of money for not-so-great tasting desserts and fruit.  When I asked her why she would eat something that doesn't taste good, she said the taste and flavor brings back good memories.  Now that my mother has past away, I long for home cooked meals that reminds me of my mother's cooking more than anything restaurants can dish out.  

Tabu is a modern restaurant - whether you go there for authenticity or creativity, you must admit, the food there taste pretty darn good
author: Duke D.

description: This is a wonderful restaurant. Love the family operation! We were a party of 7 and they couldn't do enough for us. Celebrating 3 family birthdays and decided on Tuba as my son lives in the Mission and we wanted to be able to walk to the restaurant. Food and service were terrific! Lots of interesting choices. We had a very early reservation and there were no other guests when we arrived. However, it was packed when we left. Cold Meza combination plate was so yummy, unfortunately, filled up on that. Portions were generous and everyone enjoyed their meal. They provided birthday desserts to all three family members which was awesome.  Plan on coming back even though we live in the East Bay!
author: Gail F.

description: I recently had the best Adana Kebap in the city here. This new Turkish restaurant won me over. The only disappointment was that on Yelp they offer a $5 discount and when we mentioned it to our wait staff they were confused and didn't handle it very well.
author: Gabriela H.

description: I have tried several dishes and desserts here. Tuba is one of the few restaurants in SF that keeps me coming back. Definitely not a "one-night stand" type of place. Excellent waitstaff and ambience.
author: Al G.

description: i've eaten here three times now - once by myself, once as a party of two, and then as a party of three.  Each time, the service was outstanding and friendly and conscientious - and the food was not only extremely good, the presentation was wonderful.   it's a wonderful restaurant, with wonderful food, and a friendly and attentive staff & i'll enjoy going there again and again.  It's a treasure!
author: Wolf B.

description: on sunday I was at tuba. that was my second time to be there. I brought couple friends of mine to show them how amazing Turkish foods are. they were truly impressed by the food, the place n the nice service. I would strongly recommend people to eat lamb chops, stuffed salmon, mixed grill as a main course. they are definitely splendid. and i can also tell that tuba is the best turkish restaurant in san francisco to have a nice dinner with ur friends, date and family.
author: Hilal P.

description:
Good ambience, friendly enough waiters, slow service on sun nite, pretty busy restaurant. Bottomline - if you are familiar with middle-easter food you will be disappointed. 

Great bread, Dolma was Ok, Esme was nicely presented but sucked, Moussakka was a cheesy casserole, kofte kabab was ho-hum. Will not come back as there are many better alternatives.
author: Jay K.

description: I had dinner with friends recently and was impressed with the decor of the restaurant, quite pretty (especially the colorful salt and pepper shakers) -the place had a comfortable feel.  The portions are quite large and we felt they were good value for the price.  Others have complained about bland food, but this was not an issue for us - we enjoyed the falafel salad (although outer coat of the falafels were a little hard),  the adana kebab plate was delicious, as well as  the warm appetizers.   What really made our meal though was the graciousness and friendliness of the staff.   It was a pleasant time and we left feeling quite full.   I will definitely go back again to sample other platters.
author: Mary D.

description: I am greateful that a Turkish Restaurant is in my neighborhood. Lots of Vegeterian options, cozy atmosphere, helpful and always smiling waitresses. Their food might not be better than the Turkish restaurants in Turkey (and I don't know why people expect that), it is still zesty for my taste buds.
author: Serhat T.

description: Why do restaurants use such tiny tables for two people? I know restaurants can cram a few more tables in by buying tiny tables, but I think it's annoying. Even though there were larger tables for four available all during our dinner, we were seated at a dinky table where we constantly had to be careful not to push something over the edge. Adding to that, they keep a bottle of water on your table, taking up precious space. If the table is so small, why not come by with a water pitcher to refill our glasses? And, then, why serve the food on such large dishes? To make it impressive, I guess. Actually, the food was very good. Salmon was excellent, the shrimp kebab ok. They still don't have a wine list, although are pouring house wine. No decaf coffee either.
author: Jerry A.

description: The food is absolutely delicious!! I'll definitely come here again for the Kebabs that melt in your mouth..
author: Nupur B.

description: Very pleased with our first dinner at Tuba. Food was excellent, service was top notch and the owner was warm and entertaining. Best Turkish food in the city, can't wait to go again.
author: Alex K.

description: I made dinner reservations for my BFs Birthday.  The food was fresh and flavorful, the ambiance was warm and intimate.  The service was above par (and I am picky).  the only down side, there isn't a lot of parking, but thats the city.
author: Stephanie S.

description: An excellent Turish food restaurant in the Mission! It's thankfully not just a kebab place, which is what keeps opening when I'm seeking out a proper meal. The menu is fairly extensive, everything on it is delicious! We started with this cheese-filled taquito type app, it was different and quite good! The prawn salad had amazingly fresh and flavorful greens and veggies for January - I was floored that even the tomatoes were perfect. The Lamb wrap comes with a great tomato/yogurt sauce, a great menu choice.  Service is friendly and the owner is a total sweetheart that makes you want to return again and again. Right now they are BYOB/BYOW - get up on that while you can.
author: Colleen B.

description: We have been at this restaurant a few times by now.  Almost everything we had so far turned out to be delicious and properly prepared.  We still have a few more items to go through :-) Generally, we struggle in refering Turkish restaurants to our friends since most are not close to the real "thing". Tuba restaurant solves our challenge by offering many well prepred and authentic Turkish dishes. Service is great and friendly as well.
author: K K.

description:
We had a fabulous experience at Tuba. We were looking for a more casual and different experience from our usual Saturday night and we found exactly what we wanted. The restaurant was full, but they seated us at the bar and managed to make us feel like we were being well taken care of without intruding on our meal or conversation. The food was excellent. In addition to the standard middle eastern staples they had unique Turkish dishes I'd never heard of. I'm
A vegetarian so I had ezme - a unique combo of chopped walnuts and this fantastic red pepper paste served with their yummy bread - and the stuffed eggplant, which I just couldn't stop eating. The Boy, a carnivore to the core, had feta prawns and the beef & lamb kabob. He thoroughly enjoyed them both and almost licked his kabob plate clean. Oh, and don't forget to try the Turkish wine.  This is a really lovely and fun place. We'll definitely be back.
author: Kirstin A.

description: This place is really fantastic. Their kebabs are fantastic...especially the kofte and adana! We started going here when the restaurant was BYOB, but even now that they have a $10 corkage, we love bringing nice bottles here. The staff is always friendly. Did I mention the food was fantastic?
author: Ben E.

description: Found this place last nite--and was impressed.  I had the beef/lamb kabob which was delish--ate everything on the plate and then some.  Nice portions and the bread is really good.  Pretty authentic food.  Would definitely go back and try other dishes.
author: Nancy H.

description:
Tuba is for me the best combination of Mediterranean (greek-turkish...) food in a sophisticated ambience I have visited so far (without including the luxurious Persian restaurants). It just opened this year on Guerrero and 22nd, in San Francisco, and I was very happy with the discovery. 
I had the tomato, onion and cucumber salad, a big platter full of fresh red delicious ripe vine tomato with the perfect Mediterranean seasoning of oil and vinegar, and leaves of mint very well cut so the aroma and flavour is not too intrusive. 
My entree was the eggplant puree with lamb and tomato sauce. It was light, perfect amount of food and very nice combination of flavours, although next time I will order the lamb ribs, which I saw them being served to another customer and they looked just as if I was back home in Spain: small. juicy surrounded by that small and golden perfect line of lamb fat. I asked the owner why the lamb didn't have that strong aftertaste usual to find when eating lamb and he told me that the lamb he uses is local fresh lamb meat, not the usual imported frozen and cheaper lamb used in many restaurants.
The specialty dessert was good (kenafi, I think), although it is so sweet that you should better make some room for it (for intance by eating less warm bread, which in the other hand is great, with cummin).
My only concern was the hummus. It was good but I missed some thickness and taste. I have realize that lately some restaurants offer a variation of hummus that is lighter, maybe to avoid the garbanzo and garlic flavour to be too intrusive, but I miss the usual texture and taste. 
I would definetely recommend the place for a nice dinner for couples or a small group of friends. If you make a reservation, ask for one of the two window tables, they are a very cozy corner.
author: Clarisse C.

description: Dropped by last night. They had a buncha appetizers which could be made vegan, but no entrees. However we spoke to the owner and he said he'll add some vegan options in a few days! He was really nice. Looking forward to eating there!
author: jeff g.

description: Friendly service, excellent food and great decor!  I'll be back!
author: Gran A.

description: Fantastic food, great service, family feel - really unbeatable.  This place is perfect for a date, or a family dinner.  The service is incredible, feels like being an honored guest in someone's home - especially when the owner comes out twirling trays of turkish coffee.  Love it!
author: Dusty S.

description: This place would've never landed on my radar but for the coupon I had bought. Tuba is a small and cozy Turkish place that seems to take pride in their food taking care to present the food well, and more important, the food was good quality. Boyfriend ordered a kebab (sirloin+lamb mix) and it was fab. At the waitress' suggestion, I ordered a manti (sp?) which is a turkish ravioli essentially. The other time I had manti before, it was disappointing and after hearing our waitress rave about it, I thought I'd give it another try. Sorry but I still don't love it. Nonetheless, it was seasoned well and well-made. Just not my thing. Service is five-stars. All the servers were very attentive.
author: Rita C.

description: This is an amazing place with super nice wait staff.  The food was fresh and kept us guessing at the flavors.  They really jumped out in your mouth.  The only item that was not great was the crab cake in the warm plate sampler.  It was too fishy and not very fresh, but it was a crowded night at the end of the day.  The rest was delicious and we had to take it home to finish it the next day for lunch.  I look forward to giving this place another try.
author: A J.

description: First time at this restaurant and I was VERY impressed.  We ordered the fallafel salad, salmon, and the mousakka.  The salmon was a 2.5 out of 5, but the fallafel salad and mousakaa were both 4.5 out of 5.  The food was delicious, fresh, and nicely prepared.  We received the food warm, garnished, and in large portions.  Definitely a fan and will be a repeat customer!
author: Trish S.

description: My husband found this place and its GREAT! We really like the food. It has great vegetarian options! The owner and his family are all really really nice as well! Would def. recommend this place!
author: Purvi B.

description: I came here last friday for the first time with a friend. We didn't have a reservation but we were promptly seated. The service was super friendly and attentive. We ordered the Tuba Hot Platter for the appetizer and split the musakka for the entree. Both dishes were delicious! I like that you can enjoy a nice (european style) dinner here and take your time. I will definitely be back!
author: M J.

description: Love!  Delicious food (especially the meat dumplings - a must have), cozy atmosphere, and good service.  A great addition to the neighborhood.
author: Melinda C.

description: Great selection of flavorful, fresh and well prepared Turkish and middle-Eastern dishes.  Service was friendly and efficient.  The variety of mezzes to start the meal is amazing, but don't fill up on them because the main courses and desserts can't be missed.
author: Bruce M.

description: The food was good but the service was really bad. if  i was the owner, i would want my employees have manners. this person i think she said her name was Mini, she should not be working at the restaurant business, she doesn't understand English well and she is also rude. i don't think i will come back.
author: Alicia S.

description: the best turkish restaurant. food was excellent and service was 5 stars. great vibe. the owner and his son went out of their way to make us feel welcome and well taken care of .  will definitely eat here again and again. :)
author: Mark S.

description: I loved eating there. I was visiting San Francisco, and a friend took us the restaurant. I am Turkish, and when I eat there I felt right at my home country, Turkey. Everything we ordered was very delicious, and very high quality. The owner and the people was very friendly and service was great. It might be very crowded, so make reservation before go. I definitely recommend lentil soup, and lamp kebab. Please, please try "Kunefe". I cook myself at home, but this one was just perfect, not very buttery, and not over sweet.
author: Nermin N.

description: if you love Turkish food (and how can you not?) you'll enjoy Tuba - the staff are charming, gracious and helpful - prices are a little bit high, but you certainly get your money's worth - my shrimp dish looked like too much food, but somehow I ate almost every bite!  our dessert was a little disappointing to me (looked like a philo turnover) - baklava might be a better choice - one of our party had a birthday and they brought over the most amazing chocolate pyramid as a comp - I might go for that next time!  parking is not as terrible as on Valencia (we had a 6:30 reservation on a Thursday) - reservations are definitely recommended as this place is very popular (deservedly)
author: Nancy M.

description: From the time that you come in from the time you leave, the people that work there are friendly. I got a groupon for this restaurant and being that I live in front of the place, I thought that was a great opportunity. The food was good, big enough for the price. It was tasty. I would go back again and happy its in my neighborhood.
author: Sheyla A.

description: Was able to get a seat here on a Friday night, although I'd recommend reservations as they do seem to fill up on weekends. The BYO was fantastic. The food was delicious. Everything tasted good, the prices were reasonable (especially factoring in the alcohol), and service was slow but nice. I think they're new and working out some kinks, but this restaurant is very promising.
author: Anonymous F.

description:
First, I'll give credit where credit is due. I love the dolmas-- they have a unique texture and flavor with delicious spices. The stuffed eggplant is really good, and the salmon is pretty top-notch (they manage to get the skin perfectly crispy--not easy!) The atmosphere is also inviting, with nice low lighting and cool art on the walls.

But honestly, I've been there twice now and have to say the service was truly sub-par. The first time I tried Tuba, it had just opened up and I guess they weren't getting much business yet. My girlfriend and I were one of two parties in the place, and the waiter was practically breathing down our necks the entire meal. When he wasn't checking in on us every five minutes, the entire waitstaff was just standing around the back of the restaurant staring at us. Um...awkward. Not to mention how every time someone stopped to look at the menu in the window, the manager would literally SPRINT across the restaurant, run outside, and beg them to come inside. One time I think he went an entire block to chase someone down. Hey Tuba? Desperation is not appetizing.

Then at the end of the meal, I decided to order a cup of coffee (my girlfriend had the Turkish coffee which she said tasted like dirt, but maybe that's just her taste). So when the waiter brings the cup, I add cream, stir it up, and get ready to enjoy a nice coffee...until I take a sip and...it's definitely a strange tasting coffee. And by that I mean it wasn't coffee. It was tea. Yeahhhh tea. Majorly disappointing.

The second time I went to Tuba they at least got the order right, but they can't seem to get the timing down. The appetizer came fast enough, but then there was a weirdly long wait before the entree. The waitress was kind of chilly, too, like she was mad at us or wanted to kill us, or something.

So, although the food is definitely tasty, it's not out of this world-- and when you combine that with crappy service I'm just not thrilled with Tuba.
author: J P.

description: Having been to Turkey, I can attest that was was dished out at Tuba bears no resemblance to what is actually served in that country. This had to be the most boring, anesthetized version I have ever had the displeasure to encounter. Everything was bland and boring, the portions were minuscule, the only good thing was the bread, but that hardly makes eating here worth the tariff.
author: Carla B.

description: In preparation for my upcoming trip to Turkey, I ventured out to this well recommended restaurant for a taste of Turkish delight.  To my delight, I found a great neighborhood gem that I will certainly revisit.  My meal started with a delcious lentil soup and for my main course I had their cold appetizer sampler platter.  This was not much different than other middle eastern samplers but each dip and salad had a special flare.  The one item that stood out most was surprisingly the humus.  It was silky, not grainy at all, flavorful without having a garlicky aftertaste.  Delicious!  The staff was friendly and helpful with our food selection. The owner/chef stopped by to greet us and ask about our dining experience. This place is a great find!
author: Ralph C.

description: Delicious food, sexy ambience, excellent service. There is, by the way, no outdoor seating. A little more expensive than I can afford. Good for dates.
author: Jade P.

description:
Opening night, the place was a hit.
The Boy and I had appetizers, entrees and dessert there tonight, and had absolutely nothing bad to say.
Seriously.
Nothing.

First, the bread. Amazing, fresh out of the oven, studded with... something tasty, kinda salty... anyway, perfect. And some sort of peppered, cilantro'd butter made out of heaven and happiness. We kind of ate too much of it, honestly, especially once our waiter, Michael, brought out some sort of yoghurty dip and some spicy red stuff.

We started with crab cakes for me and lentil soup for him. The crab cakes had this awesome consistency, soft and moist with a crunchy crust, and a bonus surprise of toasted pine nuts! What a perfect addition! It came with a salad that had this perfectly tangy dressing with just a hint of spice. Killer. I had trouble sharing. Boy's lentil soup was delicious, flavorful without being too salty, and again, with a hint of tang. Mediterranean. That's the thing. Right? Anyway, delicious.

That reminds me. Never, during the course of our meal, did we reach for the salt or pepper. Everything was perfectly seasoned. 

Entrees. Yes. I had the lamb chops, Boy had the Salmon. Amazing. The salmon was perfectly tender, seasoned but not overly so. It was a great piece of fish, and you could taste it. The seasoning, and the slight bitterness in the rice (bay?) complemented, instead of covering, the taste. The lamb was perfectly cooked, with herbs that combined to make some sort of magical aura around the lamb, but I couldn't identify if you paid me a million dollars, on a bed of the same rice as the salmon, with some awesome kindofmaybe pickled carrots, zucchini and maybe cucumber? Anyway, awesome, and perfect consistency, a slight crunch, but not too much. 

Dessert! Boy had this incredible pyramid of panna cotta. Something like chocolate, then regular, then dark chocolate? It was some sort of creamy custardy chocolatey thing, then the most perfect panna cotta ever invented. Seriously. The whole thing was shaped into a pyramid, then covered in dark chocolate the Incas and Egyptians would be jealous of, mottled with white chocolate in cute little stripes, then surrounded in (mango? apricot? mangicot?) syrupy-puree stuff that had me literally licking his plate. When he wasn't looking. Because he's embarrassed by me sometimes. I had the house specialty, a (guys, I loved it so much I copied from the menu and emailed it to my mother with a picture) "Kunefe: Two layers of kadayif (shredded fillo dough) filled with sweet cheese, baked to perfection, and served with homemade syrup and pistachio nuts" Salty-sweet, warm in the middle with a cool syrup, crunchy and delicious, I can see why it was the house special. I can't wait to go back and try the other one I couldn't pronounce. 

Both of us had Turkish Coffee with dessert, which explains why I'm in Shotwell's Bar at 11:50 pm buzzing and drinking red wine and writing this review. OMGWHOAGUYS


Anyway, highly recommended, a great asset to that block, which already has some excellent businesses (Tao is amazing, people. Why you don't eat there is a mystery to me, but do me a favor and don't take our table if you all of a sudden discover the place. Also, Que Tal is an awesome place to waste a morning, or work, whatever, and Liberties is a gem.) and hopefully won't fall prey to the same curse that has killed many a restaurant in that space. 

Also, apparently they need a tuba. Anyone got one they're getting rid of?
author: Rhiannon C.

description: We had a wonderful meal here last night without breaking the bank. I had never heard of this place, but after combing yelp for something that seemed interesting but not too expensive, we think we scored. When we arrived, we felt like we were being welcomed into someone's home. The manager (owner?), greeted us like long lost friends. Service from start to finish was efficient and very personable and seemed to be quick without making us feel rushed. We got to sample a few by-the-glass wines before making our decision. They brought out warm flat bread with olives, feta and humus. Very yummy. We had the crab cake appetizer which was delicious. Very crabby (in a good way) and nice crisp crust on the outside (made with bulgar, I think). My entree was the beef manti. Loved the dainty little pockets and the sauce was just great. Hubby had the chicken shishkabobs which can be the epitome of sameness. This was just great. The meat was tender and flavorful. Loved the grilled veggies with it. The sole reason we picked this restaurant was to satisfy my craving for kunafe. I've had kunafe at a few other spots in the city, but this one was my favorite so far. Washed down with turkish coffee, we left stuffed and happy. As we left, we were escorted out by the manager. Really, we felt like we were regulars and if we lived closer, we probably would be. Servings were generous. With appetizers, wine, entrees and dessert for under $90! That's pretty good for San Francisco. I really can't wait to go back.
author: Lynn L.

description:
This place is fantastic, and really underrated. It doesn't look all that from the outside, but once you get inside it is gorgeous - lots of wood, bright cushions and fabrics, interesting modern artwork and colored glassware. It feels a bit like stepping into a very stylish pasha's tent.
The service is fantastic, really friendly and helpful but unobtrusive, and very kind to single diners coming in by themselves to enjoy a delicious meal over a book (there have always been several of these in there whenever I go - and it is great to find a restaurant that treats us solo diners well).
The food - wow! Very authentic, varied and tasty. The dips, cold meze and vegetables sides are all great (especially the zucchini fritters) but the starring role has to be the meat, which is what I am usually craving when I end up here.
Succulent, perfectly spiced kebabs, lamb chops and kofte grilled over a high heat to get that lovely crust on the outside, but remain tender and delicious. These guys are artists at this. The mixed grill is the best showcase for their skill - enough to share (or take half home if you are dining alone) and with a fantastic side of herbed, sauteed (I think?) carrot and zucchini and thinly sliced pickled red onion.
Excellent wine list too - some unusual middle-eastern wines and a good selection of cheaper/more familiar Californian and South American options, with a good range of by-the-glass prices.
author: Alex G.

description: good food, very reasonable pricing. lamb chop medium rare was super delicious and moist. the hot appetizer sampler was really good as well...except for the falafel. large portions, you can even share the mix kabob entree between 2 people. should also make reservation, the restaurant is small and tightly packed
author: Long C.

description:
I went to Tuba last week with my mom who was in from LA and the food was simply delicious.  Started out with the crispy feta cheese appetizer (perfect for sharing) and then had the Kofte Kebab for dinner - mom had lamb chops.  It was served with rice and veggies so the entire plate was quite substantial.  And even though we were full, we still had this delicious dessert who's name escapes me...

The service was very good - friendly, attentive, helpful.  And since we didn't have drinks, the whole bill came to $45 which I thought was a bargain.  

Can't wait to go back!!
author: Jill F.

description: We went here for Valentine's Day.  I was a bit disappointed that they jacked up the prices for V Day.  A chicken shish kabbob was $19.  It was very good but not worth $19.  The Turkish beer was very good.  I will come back on a non-holiday because overall the restaurant is very good and a nice taste of Turkish cuisine.
author: Nick L.

description: A lot like its musical namesake, the food at Tuba was fun to try, but  needs some accompaniment. By my count there have been about 4 restaurants in this same spot over the past 5 years, and I would put Tuba somewhere in the middle of that group.  The feta shrimp we started out with were OK...they tasted as if they had been shelled before cooking, rather than after, which tends to drain the flavor.  My main course was beyti:  ground lamb and beef with spices, yogurt and tomato sauce.  It was fine, but a little bland.  The tomato sauce honestly tasted like it had just been poured from a can, and had zero pizazz.  The chicken kebab was also just fine, but was a little dry and lacking it spice.  The service was friendly.
author: Aaron S.

description: I really think this is by far the best Turkish Restaurant in the bay area. I am Turkish and I tried Sultana, Alaturka, Med Gill, etc. This place is by far better than any other place I tried. Adana Kebap is almost the same as the real deal in Turkey. Dolmas are home made. Kunefe is absolutely delicious. Last night I ate there, the bathroom did not have soap. I hope they address that issue. But it was spotless clean which is also welcome change as compared to some other Turkish restaurants. Decor also is very inviting. Parking is easy and you can bring your drink which makes the whole deal a lot cheaper.
author: bora o.

description: Great experience.  Turkish beer and wine appetizer sampler is good to share.  Kabobs were perfectly cooked and juicy.
author: John P.

description: I went to Tuba with a couple of friends, and we have enjoyed our time very much. The food was superb, I loved the Adana Kebab and the rice pudding. Kunefe is also a very tasty desert. The envorinment is very relaxing, the staff were very caring and we had good service at our table. I would recommend Tuba to anyone who would like to try the best Turkish cuisine in San Francisco. It is a very suitable restaurant for family and friend get togethers as well as couples.  We will definitely go back to Tuba soon.
author: Frankie M.

description: Great ambiance, and I love the spicy ezme appetizer!
author: Steve S.

description: We ordered the kofte as appetizer and Beyti Adana as entree.   Former was mediocre at best, but the latter was pretty good.  It wasn't orgasmic or anything.   I'd have rated the place 4 stars but the slightly inattentive service knocked it down a half notch.
author: Chaz N.

description:
Tasty Turkish food. The Greek salad (with feta and dried cranberries) is amazing. I also recommend the kofta kebab. 

A tad pricey for Turkish food ($13-14 kebabs), but the portions were big. I'll definitely go back.
author: Jennifer P.

description: This is really a wonderful neighborhood restaurant.  It is a an intimate little place with great service!  My waiter made some excellent recommendations.  My appetizer arrived very quickly and wasn't quite hot enough, but it was tasty.  My entree was really wonderful, straight from the grill and artfully plated.  The real treat though was the dessert, Kilnefe, a classic Turkish dessert.  It was absolutely fabulous.  I really recommend this little spot.
author: Mary O.

description: As others mentioned, the bread and falafel salad are really yummy. Had the salad as my main meal for dinner, and the portion was more than enough.  Service was great, and it's BYOB right now so I just walked in with a couple beers and they opened & poured them in glasses for us.
author: l c.

description: I wish my stomach was bigger.  'Nuff said.
author: Bobbi C.

description: Serefe! What a spot for our Turkish mate's 31st bday. It's about time the launch a class Turkish restaurant in SF. We have been looking for years. The service is splendid and if you get in there soon you will hopefully still get their BYOB special with no corkage since they don't have their liquor license yet. This place is a ton of fun with a group. Delicious too. Their Baklava is out of this world, take me to a secluded beach in Bursa type of amazing!
author: Scott D.

description: Delicious Turkish food; reasonable prices; casual, comfy atmosphere; big portions; nice, attentive service. Need I say more? OK, I will. 6 of us for dinner last night and everyone enjoyed their meal. We ordered 3 hot appetizers with extra portions for all 6, 1 cold appetizer combo plate, 6 separate entrees and 3 desserts. Final cost was $33/each including tip. We all ate very well and the food was nicely prepared and tasty. Staff was friendly, attentive and helpful, but not smothering and hovering. I will definitely go back.
author: joshua s.

description: Went here on a groupon date, and was not what I expected.  The service was relaxed but attentive (we sat at the bar, the bartender was very personable, allowed us to taste all the wines we were interested in), ambience was great, and food was good.  It was a good place to sit at the bar and share a few plates.
author: Connor S.

description: Quite a pleasant experience. Lamb chops were truly spectacular - perfectly grilled and spiced. Some of the best I have ever had. Steak and chicken kebabs were a little bland - could do with more spices, and a hot red sauce would be a welcome addition to the serving. Goat-cheese-stuffed falafel salad also a high point. Several wines were not available, and those that were were overpriced.
author: Jonathan M.

description: Great butter. Sampler app was just okay. Mini beef raviolis were decent. Pureed eggplant with lamb on top was delish. Liked the efes beer.
author: Daniel K.

description: The food here was the best Mediterranean in the city!   The only thing preventing a five star rating was the time it took to bring out our meal.  However the waiter was very nice and did acknowledge  the delay which is more than most would do.  I rack the delay up to being a new restaurant.
author: Andy A.

description: The food here is excellent!  The service was okay until they got crowded, then we felt like we were being rushed out.  But, that won't keep me from going back!
author: TJ K.

description: Great addition to the neighborhood. Wonderful service, loved the food and the prices were so reasonable. We will be back and bring some friends!
author: Marie H.

description:
Have been here a couple of times. The first time, a couple of weeks after they opened, we went early on a weeknight, so it was not crowded & was very quiet. The owner spent a lot of time talking to us & recommending food. Very relaxed experience & the food was terrific. We had the cold appetizer platter, the cheese-stuffed falafel salad, the moussaka, & the kunefe for desert.
Our second visit was the opposite experience. We had reservations for a group early on a Friday night. It turned out to be their first day back in business after closing for almost a week for kitchen renovations. The food & service were still good, but there were major problems in the kitchen. It took forever to get our food & two of our party did not get their entrees until long after the desert menus arrived. However, our waiter was very apologetic & helpful explaining about the kitchen problems & comping some of our food. Not the greatest dining experience--but definitely a memorable one.
Even after the stress of our second visit, I'm still looking forward to going back to Tuba.  The food is so good and in the end, that's the most important thing.
author: Wan T.

description:
Tuba serves very good Turkish cuisine at reasonable prices in a comfortable atmosphere.  It is a great neighborhood place for a casual meal.  The food is fresh and tasty and largely authentically Turkish with a few diversions into Italy and Greece.  I would particularly recommend the seasoned lamb served with an eggplant puree -- it is tasty, satisfying and quite different from typical "Mediterranean" offerings. 

The services is friendly and good.  The lack of a liquor license (for the moment) is a bit of downside but you can bring your own.
author: Peter H.

description: We went here on a groupon. Even without it, the menu items were moderately priced. The staff was attentive. The one hiccup was with the first impression; the first hot appetizer, the fried zucchini cakes, arrived soggy and cold.  However, the falafel had nice flavor and were served piping hot, crunchy on the outside, light and fluffly on the inside.
author: Greg C.

description: I have been returning a lot to this sweet little hide away on Guerrero.
author: Noelle M.

description: So far the west coast has subpar middle eastern (most places don't make their own bread) but this place is pretty decent for SF middle eastern.  Bonus points for being so close to where I live.  The Hummus is surprisingly delicious.
author: Z M.

description:
I guess I like Turkish food, since I've liked all the Turkish restaurants I've attended.  At Tuba, the bread and seasoned butter (with garlic, herbs, and peppers, perhaps?) were one of the highlights; impulse control kept me from eating the whole basket.  The tomato, cuke, and onion salad was well-seasoned, but the tomatoes lacked flavor.

The lamb kebab was tasty.  The amount of meat was modest - perhaps 3 or 4 oz. total - but I was grateful because then I felt free to indulge in dessert.  The kunefe dessert was like a grilled cheese sandwich soaked in syrup, which is a good thing in my book.  I'm glad I shared it, though - it's too rich to eat alone.

Good service.
author: Sumomo O.

description: falafels stuffed with goat cheese. need i say more?  really excellent food and great wine selection. highly recommend if you're craving a kebab.
author: Courtney B.

description: I was extremely happy to find this little gem of a restaurant. The food was delicious, the atmosphere very comfortable, and the meals were surprisingly inexpensive. In fact, we had a coupon for $50 off a $100 purchase, and we had a difficult time spending that much money between the three of us! Adam, the owner, was great, and made the dining experience very warm. I highly recommend it! We were there when they first opened, so they still didn't have their liquor license, but hey were kind enough to let us bring in our own wine without a corking fee.
author: J B.

description: Excellent food? Great service. Hot plate appetizers and Adana kebab was excellent. Very highly recommended.
author: Sabri S.

description: Food was delicious and waitstaff pleasant.  If the place were more "tarted up or upscale" it could do business almost anywhere in the city.  Somewhat noisy, but otherwise really fun and good value.
author: h f.

description: Great value, HUGE portions, good food.  Reasonable price list.  What more so you want??  A neighbor gem.  Try it
author: David J.

description:
My husband is Turkish so we have been to all the Turkish restaurants in SF.  This one is definitely the best all-around in terms of atmosphere, service, and food.  The appetizers were top-notch and the entree that I had was delicious.

For Bette's information, the bread they serve is Pide, which is the typical Turkish bread served with appetizers (meze).  And the tea served in the "shot glasses" is the way it is always served.  You should get out more.
author: L. J. C.

description:
I really liked Tuba.  Not only is it a welcome addition to the 22nd St corridor, but the food is yummy and the portions represent a great value.  The service was great, attentive, but not intrusive and the design was warm and inviting/relaxing.  

The recommended appetizers were perfect and my lamb kebab was cooked perfectly med rare and served with roasted veggies and rice.  

A couple of dings:  No beer/wine license yet, but that won't take much longer.  The dessert of oven-baked rice pudding arrived cold (as in refrigerated).  Would have been a winner if served warm.  

Lastly, and oddly, there was an auto air freshener somewhere close by our table that put out this rather strong citrus smell that detracted from our very yummy smelling dinner.
author: David L.

description: Tuba was great!!!  A turkish friend recommended Tuba.  The food was great, the people were very nice and the price was good for the amount of food you received.  I will definitely be recommending Tuba to my friends.
author: Ann S.

description: This place is awesome!!!! Highly recommend it.  Best Mediterranean food in the city (I tthink).
author: Woodsman 1.

description: A cozy spot in the Mission, food was average at a decent value, nothing to write home about.  The place was busy on a Saturday evening, but, fortunately, we had a reservation for our party of 5.  Service was good and our waitress was patient even though we dawdled over the menu and asked for a minute and another minute and yet another couple minutes to decide on our order.  The table shared the sigara boregi and Tuba cold platter which was pretty standard mediterranean fare.  The dill yogurt was quite good, the best of the sampler platter.  I was disappointed by the kufte kebab which was still too pink on the inside to eat without being on E. coli watch for the next 24-48 hours.  BF's adana kebab, on the other hand, was a little dry and overcooked.  Not sure how the other entrees fared, but I didn't hear any oohs and ahhs from the rest of our table.  We had good company and our meal didn't break the bank, but....NEXT!
author: Liz N.

description: A very pleasant atmosphere for some delicious food. Not a lot of choices for vegetarians, but don't miss the moussaka. The two of us ordered two dishes, no appetizers, and were too full to try the desserts. Next time!
author: Alvin O.

description: GREAT FOOD!  Our waiter gave us a great history on Turkish food, and was very attentive. Will definetly recommend this restaurant to friends who plan to visit S.F.
author: A O.

description: I'm a Turk who has lived in the Bay Area for more than 15 years. I have been to just about all the Turkish restaurants that ever opened up.  Up until now, when my friends asked me to recommend a Turkish restaurant, I was always hesitant since I've never been too impressed with any of the offerings in the area.  However with the arrival of Tuba, I can safely recommend this to everyone I know - it is by far the best Turkish restaurant I've been to in the past 15 years, and I highly recommend it. Their cold & hot appetizers are especially good - mucver, mercimek koftesi, icli kofte, sigara boregi and ezme were delicious. You should also try the hot, sweet, cheese dessert called kunefe - you won't be disappointed!!!! The first time I was there was on Friday and the place was packed for the entire 2-3 hours we were there (reservations recommended).
author: B B.

description: Tuba was really nice.  I really liked the friendly waitstaff and the food was very yummy.  We had a lamb special and the little dumplings (appetizer?).  And a lot of other stuff to share with our friends (definitely share!)   It's a pity it wasn't busier on a Saturday night as it a great place worthy or repeat business!
author: Louise T.

description: Though I've tried Mediterranean cuisine, this was my first foray into Turkish food...and it was delicious. I've already been lured to Tuba twice since it's grand opening this month.  The atmosphere is intimate and cozy; a perfect place to escape the winter rains.  The staff was informative, attentive and gracious.  All the dishes were very tasty--well seasoned, the meat perfectly cooked.  My absolute favorite entree was the Hunkar Begendi (pureed eggplant with lamb).  I also can't get enough of the kunefe, a cheese-filled pastry.  I've already started researching recipes, but I can only dream of recreating Tuba's version of this perfectly sweet dessert!
author: Dina D.

description: A great addition to this neighborhood.  Really friendly service and great food.  The hot and cold platters have always been great.
author: J A.

description: It was good, but not good enough for me to go back.  The baked eggplant was so oily, I thought the Deepwater Horizon was underneath it.  Seriously - like a couple of tablespoons of oil on top.  The falafel salad was nice.  Yeah, about three stars...  That said, the kebabs looked pretty damn good.
author: Geoff L.

description: My son, his finance and I had dinner at Tuba last week. The food is fabulous, perfectly prepared, generous portions. We shared their country salad and it was more than enough for the three of us. I ordered the mixed shishkababs. The lamb was heavenly...could cut it with a fork! The seasoning was very authentic as well. The rice was perfectly prepared. Two dinners was sufficient for the three of us. The service was excellent, efficient and pleasant. The waiter was knowledge about all the dishes we ordered and answered all of our questions to our satisfaction. I will go back again and again. Thank you TUBA for being in my neighborhood.
author: Roseann G.

description: I felt pretty meh about this place -- I'm guessing from the other reviews it's because I don't eat meat.  I don't even remember what I ate, so it clearly wasn't very exciting.  The menu selection was pretty standard and the service was slow.  I'll probably give it second shot at some point, but given how many great restaurants there are in this neighbourhood, I'm not in a hurry to go back.
author: Sarah B.

description: Not a bad place.  Prices are decent, food is decent, decor is decent.  I had the albacore special, and it was good but not spectacular.  The hostess is Russian I think, and has a really cool accent!
author: Allie M.

description: My husband and I heard about Tuba via Groupon and I'm glad we did.  Tuba has excellent food!  For an appetizer we ordered the "Tuba Hot Platter."  Our favorite items from the platter were the crabcake and Sigara Boregi.  For an entree I had the sauteed chicken which was very good, but my husband's stuffed eggplant took the prize.  We were so full there was no room for dessert.  We cannot wait to go back for the crabcakes, stuffed eggplant, and dessert.  I highly recommend Tuba!  It's a great restaurant for couples or for a group.
author: Stephanie F.

description: Very happy Tuba has opened in our neighborhood!  We had a lovely dinner here tonight. Started with boregi, dolma, kofte w/bulgar, and white bean salad. All were delicious.  For our entree we had the Mixed Grill II. Enough meat for 4 people!  At least we have leftovers.  Dessert was rice pudding and Kanafeh. The rice pudding was mediocre. I think it would have been better without the mango tasting stuff that was on top. Just serve it like they do in Turkey!  The timing was off a bit but our waiter acknowledged this and the manager more than made up for any down time by stopping by to chat.  We did have to run home to grab a bottle of wine (no biggie since we live a block away) but I think they should note this on Open Table or on their website (which is still down?)  All in all, we look forward to going back soon!
author: Clarice C.

description: excellent service, just about right ! friendly waiter and owner came to our table couple of times, food = stuffed goat cheese falafel is a must , appetizer plate was very neat and had some good flavor , the grill combination was good as well but i think more seasoning doesnt hurt , meat is average quality but cooked perfectly , rice and grilled veggies were superb , no room for dessert that would be next time wish them all the luck of course
author: NAEL K.
